entries: A character who succeeds on una tirada d'Intel·ligència ({@skill Religió}) amb CD 15 recognizes this statue as another representation of Sseth.

entries.name: 10. Rainfall Caverns
entries: Water pours from the ceiling of these 20-foot-high caves like a heavy rain. Consequently, creatures in this area have disadvantage a tirades d'habilitat de Saviesa ({@skill Percepció}) que involucrin la vista or sound.

entries.name: 10a. Venom Pool
entries: This cavern is flooded to a depth of 4 feet. The water glows green around an emerald that lies on the floor in the middle of the cavern. This gemstone has been blessed by Sseth, such that it turns the water around it to poison. Any creature that starts its turn in the water ha de salvar per Constitució (CD 12), taking 11 ({@dice 2d10}) de dany de verí; si supera, en rep la meitat. Water that leaves the cavern is no longer poisonous, and the water in the cavern ceases to be poisonous once the emerald is removed from it.

entries.name: Tresor
entries: The flawed emerald loses its magic if taken from the area and is worth 250 gp.

entries.name: 10b. Hissing Stone
entries: In the middle of this cavern, a large stone rises above the 3-foot-deep water and magically emits a soft hissing sound. The natural pattern of the stone vaguely resembles a swarm of snakes.

A character who touches the stone hears a sibilant whisper asking that individual to ask a question aloud. If the character does so, the voice answers as if the character had cast the {@spell auguri} spell. Once the stone is used in this way, it cannot be used again until the next dawn.

entries.name: 11. Watch Post
entries: This area is guarded by thralls of the Ssethian Scourges against possible attack from the Blacktongues.

entries.name: 11a. Flooded Cave
entries: This 20-foot-high cavern is flooded with muddy water to a depth of 3 feet. The drow in area 11b attack intruders they spot moving through this cave.

entries.name: 11b. Watchers in the Dark
entries: Dry land rises gently out of the water to create a broad ledge dotted with 4-foot-high piles of loose rocks. Two {@creature Drow Elite Warrior||drow elite warriors}, a female named Dirzanna Freth and a male named Arachnafein Zaphrorzza, hide behind the rocks. These drow are under the effect of the spirit nagas' {@item rod of rulership} and move to the swamp's edge to attack intruders detected in area 11a. If enemies close to melee range, the drow switch to melee weapons.

If one drow elite warrior falls in battle, the other tries to flee to area 13 and alert the creatures there. The drow have orders from the spirit nagas to capture intruders if possible, meaning that any character reduced to 0 hit points by a drow's atac armat cos a cos is knocked {@condition inconscient}. Characters captured by the drow are brought before the nagas in {@area area 15|479|x}.
If and when the {@condition fascinat} condition on them ends, Dirzanna and Arachnafein make their way to House Freth's base on {@adventure level 12|WDMM|12}.

entries.name: 12. Fishery
entries: This small cave has a 10-foot-high ceiling and contains a 20-foot-deep pool with a crevasse at the bottom, through which cold water bubbles up from a natural spring. The thralls of the Ssethian Scourges use the sightless cave fish that swim here as a source of food.

entries.name: 13. Detention Cave
entries: A male {@creature drow elite warrior} named Xirk Dezpeti'il is chained to one of three sets of esposes that hang from the west wall. The nagas use the esposes to bind creatures that resist the magic of their {@item rod of rulership}.

A sometime adventurer and unrepentant ne'er-do-well who pledges alliance to no one, Xirk is willing to trade information about the surrounding caves or the thralls' routine in exchange for freedom to return to the Underdark. If he is freed, he avoids combat and is not above stealing from his benefactors.

entries.name: 14. Fungal Farm
entries: Two tunnels lead into this damp, 10-foot-high cavern, which contains the following features:
{@b Spores}. A perpetual haze of spores fills the air, making the area lightly obscured.
{@b Fungi}. Small fungi are planted in neat rows and are used as a fast-growing food crop. A pile of gardening tools lies by the west tunnel entrance.

entries.name: 15. Lair of the Spirit Nagas
entries: All the caves of area 15 are either dry or have their floors covered with 1 foot of muddy water.

An alarm raised in any of these areas attracts all nearby creatures: the spirit nagas in {@area area 15c|47d|x}, as well as their thralls in {@area areas 11b|474|x}, {@area 15c|47d}, i {@area 15f|482}. The spirit nagas and their thralls avoid killing humanoid intruders if they can. Prisoners who can't be enslaved are thrown into the arena (area 15a) without their weapons and forced to fight to the death against the nagas' thralls.

entries.name: 15a. Arena
entries: The Ssethian Scourges sometimes have their thralls fight captives for their amusement. This 40-foot-high cave has the following features:
{@b Ledge}. A slope of dry land rises from a few inches above the water to a 20-foot-high ledge at area 15b.
{@b Weapons}. Shattered and abandoned weapons lie in the wet muck. (Characters forced to fight here can easily recover serviceable melee weapons from the muck and detritus.)

entries.name: 15b. Naga Thrones
entries: The north side of the ledge drops away 20 feet to the arena floor (area 15a). Two flat stones command a view of the arena and are used as thrones by the nagas.

entries.name: 15c. Steamy Den
entries: This cramped, steam-filled cave contains the following:
{@b Duergar Thrall}. Agorra Duskaxe, a female {@creature duergar}, stands guard just inside the entrance.
{@b Steamer}. Water dripping from a crack in the ceiling falls into a cylindrical metal contraption at the center of the cave, and steam billows out of it.

{@b Nagas}. Unless they have been drawn elsewhere, two {@creature Spirit Naga||spirit nagas} named Excrutha and Serakath lounge on the floor near the back of the cave (see "{@area The Ssethian Scourges|451|x}").
{@b Chest}. A wooden chest stands against the east wall.

The nagas don't fear death, but they do fear the loss or theft of their {@item rod of rulership} and will do everything they can to safeguard it. A battle here attracts the thralls from {@area areas 11b|474|x} and {@area 15f|482}, assuming they're still around.
While Agorra is under the effect of the {@item rod of rulership}, she believes the nagas to be her allies and defends them to the death. She carries the key to the esposes in {@area area 13|476|x}.

The steamer consists of two iron chambers stacked on top of each other. Magical fire burns in the bottom chamber, heating water that pours into the top chamber through the crack in the ceiling. Small holes in the sides of the top chamber allow steam to vent into the cave, keeping it warm and moist.

entries.name: Tresor
entries: One spirit naga has a {@item rod of rulership} coiled in its tail at all times. The rod's magic has been spent for the day and can't be called upon again until the next dawn.
The chest is unlocked and contains 500 pp, 330 gp, a silver necklace in the form of entwined serpents (250 gp), and a {@item spell pergamí} of {@spell modificar memòria}.

entries.name: 15d. Unused Laboratory
entries: A wooden table covered with materials d'alquímia stands against the north wall of this damp, 10-foot-high cave.

entries.name: 15e. Spring
entries: A steady stream of water pours out from a crack in the wall of this alcove. The water fills up a natural stone basin, which in turn overflows onto the muddy ground. This spring provides clean water.

entries.name: 15f. Troll Guard Post
entries: Two {@creature Troll||trolls} {@condition fascinat} by the nagas' {@item rod of rulership} are crammed in this alcove until they are drawn elsewhere.

entries.name: 16. Lair of the Bone Naga

entries: {@b Bones}. This 30-foot-high cave appears empty except for the bones of numerous creatures (humanoids and yuan-ti) visible beneath the water.
{@b Hexacali}. Lurking amid the bones is a {@creature Bone Naga (Spirit)||bone naga} (formerly a spirit naga named Hexacali).

The bone naga tries to slay any living creature that enters its domain. Creatures moving through this area must succeed on una tirada de Saviesa ({@skill Percepció}) amb CD 15 or be surprised when the bone naga attacks.

entries.name: 17. Battlefield Cavern
entries: This 30-foot-high cavern was the main front of the battle between the yuan-ti and the nagas.

entries.name: 17a. Bones in the Mud
entries: The water here is 2 feet deep, and the cavern floor beneath it is littered with yuan-ti bones.

entries.name: 17b. Death of a Naga
entries: The phantasmal scene of a spirit naga battling four yuan-ti purassangs plays out for characters who set foot on this island. As characters view the scene, they find themselves literally being drawn into it.

Each character drawn into the scene temporarily becomes one of the yuan-ti fighting the wounded Hexacali. The character gains the statistics of a {@creature yuan-ti purassang} with {@dice 2d20} hit points remaining.

Hexacali, a {@creature spirit naga} with 35 hit points, is trapped on the island and fights yuan-ti characters to the death. Yuan-ti characters who drop to 0 hit points during this fight immediately come to their senses and take 22 ({@dice 4d10}) de dany psíquic from the shock of their illusory demise. Unlike any damage sustained in the battle, this psychic damage is real. A character free of the vision can free another character from it by using an action to shake or slap them.

If the characters defeat Hexacali, their last collective memory is of pinning the naga down to be slain and raised as a bone naga. The vision then ends for all characters and can't take hold of them again.

entries.name: 17c. Mirror Gate to Level 10
entries: A wedge of dry land rises from the water to become the floor of a 15-foot-high cave with a mirror mounted to its eastern wall.

The mirror is framed by an assemblage of hundreds of tiny interlocking stone gears. This mirror reflects normally and is one of Halaster's gates (see "{@area Gates|028|x}"). Its frame is composed of an assemblage of hundreds of tiny, interlocking stone gears. This gate's rules are as follows:

items: Any creature that inspects the frame and succeeds on una tirada de Saviesa ({@skill Percepció}) amb CD 15 sees that one of the gears has popped out slightly. If it is pressed, the gear locks in place, causing all the gears to turn and the gate to open durant 1 minut. When the gate closes, a different random gear pops out slightly, causing all the gears to lock again.

Characters must be 11th level or higher to pass through this gate (see "{@area Jhesiyra Kestellharp|016|x}"). The first creature to pass through the gate triggers an elder rune (see "{@area Elder Runes|027|x}").
A creature that passes through the gate appears in {@area area 25b on level 10|5d1|x}, in the closest unoccupied space next to the identical gate located there.

entries.name: 18. Serpent Gate
entries: These 10-foot-high side caverns feature a standing gate that grants access to {@adventure level 11|WDMM|11}. Strikingly beautiful carvings of serpents decorate the walls of these caverns.

entries.name: 18a. Trapped Approach
entries: An old yuan-ti trap meant to prevent approach to the gate still functions in this area. A pressure plate under the water and mud extends the full width of the cavern entrance. A character searching the cavern for traps who succeeds on una tirada de Saviesa ({@skill Percepció}) amb CD 20 spots the pressure plate. The trap triggers whenever a weight of 50 pounds or more is placed on the pressure plate. Darts fire from holes in the walls against the creature that triggered the trap, making a atac armat a distància (+7 a impactar) that deals 10 ({@dice 4d4}) de dany perforant. The trap resets each round.

A search of the walls and a successful DC 20 Saviesa ({@skill Percepció}) check is sufficient to spot small holes in the serpent carvings. The characters can spend 1 minute to plug the holes, which prevents the trap from attacking. The pressure plate can be disabled una tirada de Destresa (CD 15) using thieves' tools.

entries.name: 18b. Standing Gate to Level 11
entries: Two pillars with giant stone snakes wrapped around them rise from the muck. Chiseled into the lintel stone across the top are the words "DON THE CRYSTAL CROWN" in Nan. This gate's rules are as follows:

items: The gate opens for 1 minute if a creature wears King Melair's crystal crown (see {@area level 6, area 11d|349|x}) while standing within 5 feet of it.

Characters must be 11th level or higher to pass through this gate (see "{@area Jhesiyra Kestellharp|016|x}"). The first creature to pass through the gate triggers an elder rune (see "{@area Elder Runes|027|x}").
A creature that passes through the gate appears in {@area area 11a on level 11|617|x}, in the closest unoccupied space next to the identical gate located there.

entries.name: 19. Yuan-ti Temple
entries: The roof of this cavern soars to a height of 80 feet, and the muddy water throughout is 2 feet deep. Dominating the cavern is a ruined yuan-ti temple filled with statues depicting the same winged serpent with its fanged mouth open. A character who succeeds on una tirada d'Intel·ligència ({@skill Religió}) amb CD 15 recognizes the statues as depictions of Sseth, a yuan-ti deity. Flickering torches on the sides of the temple illuminate the structure.

entries.name: 19a. Amphibious Guards
entries: Eight {@creature Batrac||batracs} and three {@creature Giant Frog||giant frogs} stand guard in the water outside the temple. The batracs try to paralyze intruders using their spears, the tips of which are coated with moc de portacarronya. Characters {@condition paralitzat} by the batracs' spears or swallowed by the giant frogs are brought to {@area area 19d|492|x} and held there until Kuketh can be summoned from {@area area 20|495|x} to devour them.

entries.name: 19b. Nartembruix
entries: A 10-foot-tall statue of a winged serpent stands at the entrance of the temple between two submerged stone ramps. The ramps are slippery and rise to meet the floor of a 20-foot-high antechamber, the floor of which is submerged under 1 foot of murky water.
Decorative columns carved to look like intertwined snakes line the chamber's walls.

entries.name: 19c. Nave

entries: {@b Water}. Murky water covers the floor to a depth of 1 foot.

{@b Ceiling Fresco}. This chamber has a vaulted ceiling 30 feet high. A fresco on the ceiling has mostly crumbled away, but the portions that remain suggest serpentine images that were probably quite fearsome.

{@b Statues}. Four statues of winged serpents stand to the north, two in the water and two above the waterline. (Torbit, a batrac assassin, hides behind the partially submerged statue in the northwest corner.)
{@b Platform}. Between the two middle statues, a mostly submerged ramp rises to the top of a dry platform, at the back of which is a closed door that opens into area 19d.

Torbit might have become king of the Blacktongues if not for his devotion to Kuketh. He jealously protects the temple that is his master's seat of power, killing any who enter without permission. Torbit is an {@creature assassin}, with these changes:

items: Torbit is chaotic evil.

He has these racial traits: He pot respirar aire i a l'aigua He speaks Batrac, and can parlar amb granotes i amb gripaus. He has a walking speed of 20 feet and a swimming speed of 40 feet. His long jump is up to 20 feet and his high jump is up to 10 feet, with or without a running start. He has advantage on Destresa ({@skill Sigil}) checks made to hide in swampy terrain.
In addition to his weapons, Torbit carries one piece of a shattered jade staff (see "Treasure" below).

entries.name: Tresor
entries: The foot-long piece of jade that Torbit carries was found in the muck. He doesn't realize that it's a fragment of a jade staff crafted by ancient yuan-ti that was discarded in Undermountain by Halaster years before. See {@area area 39b on level 6|3a3|x} for more information on this yuan-ti device and how it can be reassembled. By itself, the jade fragment is worth 100 gp.

entries.name: 19d. Apse
entries: This 30-foot-high chapel has the following features:

{@b Mud-Caked Statue}. Dried mud has been heaped onto a large, winged snake statue to the north, giving it a vaguely frog-like appearance. Poor-quality carved offerings and worthless stones are piled before the statue.
{@b Altar}. A stone altar in the center of the room bears carvings of serpents.

Any character who inspects the altar and succeeds on una tirada de Saviesa ({@skill Percepció}) amb CD 15 notices that one of the altar's carvings has a button carved to look like a serpent's eye. If this button is pressed, a secret compartment on the north side of the altar opens. Inside this compartment is a slender red taper (see "Treasure" below). Kuketh and the batracs are unaware of the altar's hidden compartment and the treasure within.

entries.name: Tresor
entries: The red taper is a {@item espelma of invocation} dedicated to Sseth, the neutral evil yuan-ti god. If the candle is removed from the altar by a creature that is not a yuan-ti, green mist billows up through cracks in the floor and coalesces into two {@creature Yuan-ti Abomination||yuan-ti abominations}. These temple guardians attack any creature that is not a yuan-ti. When reduced to 0 hit points, they revert to clouds of green mist and disappear without a trace.
If the yuan-ti abominations are not killed, they rid the temple of enemies and turn it into their lair.

entries.name: 20. Blacktongue Isle

entries: {@b Deep Water}. The ground falls away at all entrances to this 30-foot-high cavern, whose water is 30 feet deep.
{@b Island Village}. A dozen crude shacks sit atop a muddy, horseshoe-shaped island. Twenty-five {@creature Batrac||batracs} and six {@creature Giant Frog||giant frogs} slip in and out of the shacks.
{@b Bonfire}. A bonfire burns at the northern tip of the island, giving off pungent smoke. (The batracs keep it burning with a mixture of dried offal and fungus.)

The shacks are made from rocks mortared with mud. The batracs found here are busy raising young, mending nets, cooking, or working on other domestic necessities. They and the giant frogs are quick to respond to calls for aid from {@area area 19|48c|x}.

Harmless cave fish swim in the deep water around the island. The pool at the island's center is closed off by a submerged net that prevents fish from finding their way inside. The Blacktongues keep their unborn eggs in this pool, hidden among submerged stands of thick-fronded fungus.

entries.name: 21. Lord of Fetid Obliteration
entries: Unless he has been summoned to {@area area 19|48c|x}, the unhappy king of the Blacktongues is here.

entries.name: 21a. Hidra Den
entries: This cave has a 20-foot-high ceiling and is filled with water to a depth of 30 feet. Lurking in the muddy water at the bottom of the cave is a trained {@creature hidra}. The hidra refrains from announcing its presence or attacking until such time as Kuketh orders it to rise and kill something.

entries.name: 21b. Kuketh's Lair

entries: {@b Ledge}. A dry ledge 5 feet above the water line is strewn with bones, some with flesh still attached.

{@b Kuketh's Bed}. The eastern end of the ledge contains a pile of moldering hay and the rotting body of a giant toad. Unless it has been drawn elsewhere, Kuketh the {@creature death slaad} lounges on the hay in batrac form.

When not bossing around its subjects, Kuketh quietly ruminates on its troubles. The slaad communicates with strangers using telepathy and is willing to negotiate with characters who claim to be enemies of the Ssethian Scourges. A mercurial creature, Kuketh doesn't honor agreements for very long. Its only consistent desire is to escape from Undermountain and return to the Outer Plane of Limbo.

entries.name: 21c. Secret Vault
entries: This cave is hidden behind a secret door.

entries.name: Tresor
entries: The vault holds treasure collected by the batracs, including 56 pp, 2,417 gp, 540 sp, a platinum holy symbol of Sseth (a flying snake with bared fangs) worth 150 gp, and a {@item headband of intellect}.

entries.name: 22. Stables
entries: The Blacktongue batracs raise "livestock" in this 20-foot-high, torch-lit cavern. If the batrac handlers here are attacked, they release their carrion crawlers and shout for aid from {@area areas 19|48c|x} and {@area 23|4a1}.

entries.name: 22a. Giant Frogs
entries: Six {@creature giant frog||giant frogs} hop through shallow water in this cavern, croaking loudly while four {@creature Batrac||batracs} dump food (mostly vermin) into a trough along the northwest wall.

entries.name: 22b. Carrion Crawlers
entries: This raised dry area contains the following:
{@b Wooden Pen}. A pen made of wooden slats confines four {@creature Carrion Crawler||carrion crawlers} to the northeast. Three carrion crawler eggs are inside the pen.
{@b Eines}. Several buckets and long-handled tools for wrangling the carrion crawlers stand near the gate to the pen.

The batracs raise carrion crawlers for their poisonous mucus, but they also feed carrion crawler eggs to the hidra in {@area area 21a|498|x}. The carrion crawlers are not treated well. If released, they are as likely to attack the batracs as they are the characters.

Wood scraps gathered from throughout the level have been used to fence off this dry area from floor to ceiling. The gaps between the slats are just wide enough for a melee weapon or a carrion crawler's tentacle attack. A simple loop of rope keeps the gate closed.
{@b Muck}. This 20-foot-high cave is filled with muck to a depth of 1 foot.

{@b Batrac Shacks}. Two hovels made of stones and mud are lit by tall torches. Four {@creature Batrac||batracs} are mending tools near the shacks while two {@creature Giant Toad||giant toads} look on.

entries.name: 24. Kelp Farm
entries: Five {@creature Batrac||batracs} work kelp beds in the 6-foot-deep water of this 30-foot-high cave, while a {@creature giant toad} swims nearby. The kelp is a staple of the batracs' diet and glows with a faint green light. The light fades 10 minutes after the plant is harvested.
If they are threatened, the batracs order the giant toad to attack and call for help from {@area areas 2|458|x} and 23.

entries.name: Aftermath
entries: If the characters help Kuketh destroy or reclaim its control gem, the death slaad abandons the batracs. If Torbit is alive, he becomes the ruler of the Blacktongue tribe after Kuketh departs or is killed. It's only a matter of time, however, before the Ssethian Scourges seize him, make him one of their thralls, and take control of the batrac tribe. If all the Blacktongue batracs are defeated, the temple becomes a safe place for the characters to rest (assuming the yuan-ti abominations in {@area area 19d|492|x} haven't taken over the place).

Killing the Ssethian Scourges frees Yoastal from her curse and allows the Blacktongues to overrun the nagas' caves. Karstis and the mages of Dweomercore might be there already, though, wanting to hold those caverns. Such gains are short-lived, because the spirit nagas' Rejovenir trait ensures their return in {@dice 1d6} days.

data.name: Level 9: Dweomercore
entries: Dweomercore is an academy of magic designed to test, trap, and confound its students. The level is designed for four 10th-level characters, and characters who defeat its monsters and villains should gain enough PX to reach 11th level.

entries.name: What Dwells Here?
entries: An arcanaloth and a night hag preside over this level. Evil mages in search of arcane knowledge or Halaster's tutelage come here with their followers to train and be tested.

entries.name: Arcanaloth Headmaster
entries: An arcanaloth in league with the Mad Mage runs Dweomercore's academy of evil mages. The arcanaloth keeps its true name secret and uses {@spell ego alteració} spells to appear as Halaster.

The arcanaloth employs nycaloths and mezzoloths as guards, and it trades safe passage through Dweomercore for magic items or for assistance in dealing with an escaped devil (see "{@area Diable d'Ossos|4b1|x}"). It also tries to tempt adventurers who are arcane spellcasters into joining its academy—with free tuition!

entries.name: Wormriddle the Night Hag
entries: Wormriddle is a night hag who has four flesh gòlems at her command. She strikes foul bargains, offering spells and secrets of magic in exchange for evil acts that allow her to claim souls.

The night hag wears a mummified kitten's head around her neck as a talisman, though it has no magical properties. It testifies to her fear of cats, for Wormriddle is {@condition acovardit} while there's a feline creature within 30 feet of her that she can see or hear. The night hag also carries a lustrous black gem and a large black sack—her {@i heartstone} and her {@i soul bag}, respectively (see the "Hags" entry in the {@book Monster Manual|MM}).

entries.name: Evil Students
entries: Dweomercore's students are described below. Encounters with them can occur anywhere at any time, though they appear most often in their favorite haunts.

entries.name: Spite Harrowdale
entries: Dweomercore's most apt pupil, Spite Harrowdale, is a centuries-old wizard (NE male Rashemi human {@creature archmage} who speaks Common, Nannès, Èlfic, and Giant). He appears to be a 12-year-old boy, thanks to imbibing {@item Potion of Longevity||potions of longevity}. Spite hides the true measure of his magical talent by pretending to know only cantrips and 1st-level spells. This ruse has fooled the other students and most of his instructors, but not the arcanaloth, who is keeping a watchful eye on the wizard. Spite is the only student so far who has discerned that the headmaster is not in fact Halaster, but an arcanaloth disguised as him.

Spite has an oni companion that assumes the form of a female half-ogre named Dumara. The oni's real name is Kumar, and it has been in Spite's company most of its life. It treats Spite like an older brother, and it's the only being in whom Spite confides.

Spite wants to get his hands on a spellbook hidden in Halaster's private sanctuary ({@area area 45b|542|x}), and he'll use any kind of distraction to get it. Spite cuts a deal with the adventurers: if they distract the arcanaloth and the night hag long enough for him to steal the spellbook, Spite will show them the stairs leading down to {@adventure level 10|WDMM|10} (see {@area area 44|53d|x}). He will also tell them an Undermountain secret, determined by drawing a random card from the Secrets Deck (see {@adventure appendix C|WDMM|27}). Spite upholds his end of the deal only as long as it's to his benefit, and he tries to pin the theft of the spellbook on the adventurers once they're gone.
If the characters turn down Spite's deal, he teams up with Nylas Jowd and Skrianna Shadowdusk (see below) to destroy them.

entries.name: Cephalossk the Mind Flayer
entries: Cephalossk is a solitary mind flayer arcanist (see the sidebar in the "{@creature Mind Flayer}" entry in the {@book Monster Manual|MM}). It is a pariah among its own kind, has no allies at the academy, and isn't looking for friendship from anyone. It shadows adventurers and casts {@spell detectar pensaments} spells on them to glean their true intentions.

The mind flayer considers itself intellectually superior to everyone else, and it loathes Spite Harrowdale for being Halaster's favored pupil. Cephalossk tries to convince the characters to distract and kill Dumara (Spite's oni bodyguard) while it devours Spite's brain. In exchange for their help, Cephalossk promises to tell them "three secrets that every Undermountain explorer should know." Once it has fed on Spite's brain, Cephalossk makes good on its promise and telepathically shares the following information with the characters:

items: A mind flayer colony has taken over a level of Undermountain known as Seadeeps. (Cephalossk knows this because it has been in telepathic contact with the ulitharid on {@adventure level 17|WDMM|17}.)
Githyanki have invaded Undermountain and are trying to exterminate the mind flayer colony in Seadeeps.
Halaster has commandeered a vessel that can travel between worlds through space and hidden it somewhere in Undermountain (see {@adventure level 19|WDMM|19}).

entries: If the characters refuse to assist Cephalossk, the mind flayer attacks them.

entries.name: Pneumatic Tubes
entries: Dweomercore has a system of copper tubes, through which cylindrical copper canisters are propelled by air pressure. Each tube is 3 inches in diameter, and each canister is 9 inches long and just shy of 3 inches wide, with a screw-on copper lid. The tubes are labeled with their destinations.

Many of the level's inhabitants use these tubes to send scrolls, assignments, and missives to one another. Any object or creature able to fit in a tube (including characters in forma gasosa) can be transported from one end to the other in a matter of seconds. If timing becomes important, assume that whatever a creature inserts into a tube on its turn arrives at the destination at the start of that creature's next turn.

entries.name: Nylas Jowd
entries: Nylas Jowd (NE male Thayan human {@creature mage} with {@spell animar els morts} prepared instead of {@spell volar}) wanders the halls of Dweomercore with a pair of {@condition invisible} will-o'-wisps that obey his commands. Nylas journeyed from Thay to study under Halaster and learn the deeper secrets of necromancy, and he has all the hallmarks of a Red Wizard of Thay—namely, the red robes, the bald head, and the evil bent. He treats others as soon-to-be corpses and is more interested in their anatomy than what they say or do.

Nylas wants to turn the Horned Sisters (see below) into zombies because they have acted cruelly toward him. He asks the characters to kill them so he can raise their corpses with {@spell animar els morts} spells. If the characters refuse, Nylas and his will-o'-wisps attack them.

entries.name: Skrianna Shadowdusk
entries: Skrianna Shadowdusk (CE female Illuskan human {@creature mage}) recently enrolled in Dweomercore at Halaster's urging. She is one of the Shadowdusk family (see {@adventure level 22|WDMM|22}) and is spoiling for a challenge. Rude, stuck-up, and privileged, Skrianna shows utter disdain for "common rabble" and takes sadistic pleasure in abusing and manipulating others with her magic. She is accompanied at all times by her shield guardian bodyguard (she wears its amulet), as well as a grell valet that carries her spellbook (which contains all the spells she has prepared).
Skrianna doesn't trust new arrivals and attacks them at the slightest provocation, trusting that her bodyguard and her valet will protect her if a fight breaks out.

entries.name: The Horned Sisters
entries: Two tiefling sisters named Turbulence and Violence sought to join the Germanor Arcana of Luskan but were turned down. They served aboard pirate ships for a few years before ending up in Skullport, where they heard rumors of a secret academy for magic-users deep inside Undermountain. They fought tooth and nail to reach Dweomercore, but the place hasn't lived up to the hype. They have no friends at the academy, and they're unhappy with the quality of the instruction they've received. Now they want to leave, but the headmaster has instructed them to remain while giving them assurances that things will change for the better. Wormriddle the night hag has been keeping an eye on the sisters, who take advantage of any distraction to flee back to Skullport. They will attempt to enlist the characters to cause such a distraction.
The sisters are tiefling {@creature Mage||mages}, with these changes:

items: The sisters are lawful evil.
Each sister has these racial traits: She has resistance to fire damage. She has {@sense visió de foscor} out to a range of 60 feet. She speaks Common, Dracònic, Infernal, and Undercommon.
Each sister carries a spellbook that contains all the spells she has prepared.

entries.name: Elan Tanor'thal
entries: Elan is a {@creature drow mage} from a house that ran a lucrative slave trade operation in Skullport until it was driven out by the Xanathar Guild. He hopes to learn enough magic to one day conquer Skullport for his family. Like most drow, he is predictably treacherous. His silken words are pleasant enough, but any alliance forged with him is doomed to end badly—and most likely in bloodshed.

Elan extends the false hand of friendship to new arrivals while warning them to steer clear of the other students and the headmaster. "They're all insane," he says. He likes to hang around where the action is, so he can quietly observe where the characters keep their magic items and spellbooks (which he fully intends on claiming once they're dead).

entries.name: Diable d'Ossos
entries: A diable d'ossos was accidentally summoned in the southern wing by Yarek, an overzealous student. After killing its summoner, the devil discovered to its dismay that the magic wards of Dweomercore prevent it from escaping {@area area 47|548|x}. The arcanaloth offers adventurers safe passage through Dweomercore if they defeat the devil and send it back to els Nou Inferns.

entries.name: Exploring This Level
entries: Location descriptions for this level are keyed to map 9. There are few light sources here; creatures that reside in Dweomercore rely on {@sense visió de foscor} or create their own illumination with magic.

entries.name: 1. Entry Hall
entries: These rooms form the entrance to what was once a lavish underground mansion.

entries.name: 1a. Left Hand of Manshoon

entries: {@b Alarm}. An {@spell alarm} spell has been cast on the 20-foot-square area marked on map 9. It silently informs the headmaster in area 15 when visitors arrive.
{@b Ceiling Mosaics}. This room has a 30-foot-high arched ceiling. Bright mosaics on the arched roof depict wizards engaged in dazzling spell duels.
{@b Undead Guardian}. Floating in the middle of the room, 15 feet above the floor, is a man's withered left hand and forearm, severed at the elbow.
Responding to the {@spell alarm} spell, the {@creature arcanaloth} makes its way toward area 1 to greet the new arrivals (see the "{@area Meeting the Headmaster|4b8|x}" sidebar).

The limb belonged to a human archmage named Manshoon—or, more precisely, to one of his clones. The clone challenged Halaster to a spell duel and lost more than just the contest. Halaster turned the limb into a guardian that attacks all intruders until the Mad Mage or a creature that looks like him waves it off. The limb has the statistics of an {@creature archmage}, with these changes:

items: It is a Tiny, unaligned undead with 63 ({@dice 18d4 + 18}) hit points and {@spell plaga} prepared instead of {@spell banishment}.
It has una velocitat de vol de 30 peus, and it can hover.
It has {@sense visió a cegues} out to a range of 60 feet and is blind beyond this radius. It can't speak or hear, and it can't be {@condition encegat} or {@condition eixordat}.

entries.name: 1b. Waiting Room
entries: This room contains six stuffed armchairs with garish upholstery.

entries.name: 1c. Coat Room
entries: The walls of this room are lined with rows of bare metal hooks.

entries.name: 1d. Water Closet
entries: This room is equipped with stone sinks and toilets, each with a paraula màgica carved above it. The sink basins and toilet bowls magically fill and flush with water on command, and drain holes on their inside rims keep them from overflowing. Two {@creature Living Servent Invisible|WDMM|living servent invisibles} (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}) stand near towel racks, ready to hand out towels to guests.

entries.name: Meeting the Headmaster
entries: Characters who trigger the alarm spell in area 1 are met by the headmaster, who otherwise dwells in {@area area 15|4e6|x}. When in the company of visitors, the erudite arcanaloth tries to remain civil even while impersonating the Mad Mage. It describes the academy in glowing terms and sings the praises of its excellent students and their devotion to arcane magic. It claims to have a vested interest in all that happens inside Undermountain and bears no ill will toward adventurers who provide "a much needed sanitary service" by ridding the dungeon of pesky monsters. If the characters are just passing through on their way to the lower levels, the headmaster offers to take them to the top of the stairs leading down to {@adventure level 10|WDMM|10}. For safe passage through Dweomercore, it requires un/a dels següents:

items: A payment of one magic item per party member
Slaying the diable d'ossos in {@area area 47|548|x}

entries: If the characters choose to deal with the diable d'ossos rather than give up their magic items, the headmaster leads them south through {@area areas 2|4ba|x}, {@area 3|4bb}, {@area 6|4bf}, {@area 38|52e}, {@area 39|531}, i {@area 46|545}. It waits for them in area {@area 46b|547} while they slay the devil in {@area area 47|548|x}, then escorts them to the top of the stairs leading down to {@adventure level 10|WDMM|10} as promised. After watching them disappear down the stairs, the arcanaloth returns to {@area area 15|4e6|x}.
Visitors who decline the headmaster's offer are politely asked to return whence they came and never show their faces in Dweomercore again. Those who refuse to leave are attacked.

Any character who claims to be an arcane spellcaster in search of tutelage is invited to stay in Dweomercore and take the entrance exam. If the character accepts the offer, the headmaster uses a teleport spell to transport itself and the candidate to {@area area 11c|4d4|x}, where it suggests the character remain until the entrance exam can be scheduled. (If the party includes multiple candidates, the arcanaloth keeps them together.) In truth, the arcanaloth expects the candidate to ignore its suggestion and explore the complex further. The entrance exam is actually about how the candidate deals with the other students. Any candidate who can hold their own against the other students is granted admittance, having passed the headmaster's "exam" in so doing.
A character admitted to Dweomercore is free to wander the halls and talk to other students, until such time as that character gets into trouble and is expelled or murdered.

entries.name: 2. Trapped Hall
entries: The recessed wall of this corridor has engravings of eight wizards clutching staffs, each staff representing a different school of magic. This hall also has two hidden features:

items: When a creature enters the trapped 10-foot-square space marked on map 9 per primer cop en un torn o hi començi el torn, the medusa statue in {@area area 3|4bb|x} animates and shoots a magic arrow at the creature. (If the headmaster is accompanying characters through this hall, the arcanaloth uses a {@spell mà de mag} cantrip to press the button and deactivate the trap.)

A stone button is concealed in the north wall, disguised to look like a section of the staff that represents conjuration. A character who searches the wall spots the button with a successful DC 15 Saviesa ({@skill Percepció}) check. Pressing the button results in a loud clicking noise as the arrow trap deactivates durant 1 minut.

entries.name: 3. Medusa Junction
entries: The walls of this room rise vertically 10 feet, then angle inward to a 20-foot-high apex. In the middle of the room, standing atop a 1-foot-high cylindrical block of stone, is a statue of a scowling medusa with a longbow and an empty quiver. The statue gazes north.

When a creature sets off the trap in {@area area 2|4ba|x}, a {@condition emmetzinat} arrow materializes in the medusa's grasp as the statue animates. It immediately draws back on the bow and shoots the arrow at the creature that triggered the trap (+6 a impactar), dealing 6 ({@dice 1d8 + 2}) de dany perforant mes 14 ({@dice 4d6}) de dany de verí on a hit.

The medusa statue is a Medium object with AC 15, 50 hit points, and immunity to all damage except force damage. It weighs 1,200 pounds. A creature can use an action to try to knock the statue off its base, doing so with a successful DC 18 Força ({@skill Atletisme}) check. If it is toppled, the statue does not animate until returned to its former position. (If Wormriddle learns about the toppled statue, she and her flesh gòlems set it right before seeking to punish those responsible.)

entries.name: 4. Fresh Water Fountain
entries: {@b Fountain}. Fresh water from a natural spring pours out of the mouth of a bas-relief carved to look like Halaster's overjoyed visage, whereupon it spills into a semicircular stone basin enclosed by a 2-foot-high retaining wall before draining out through tiny holes.
{@b Guards}. Flanking the fountain are two {@b {@creature Mezzoloth||mezzoloths}.}
{@b Braziers}. Two unlit stone braziers shaped like clawed hands rise from the floor at the south end of the room.
The mezzoloths ensure that no one tampers with the academy's water supply or destroys the fountain. They otherwise pay visitors no mind.

entries.name: 5. Portrait of a Mad Mage
entries: This room is empty except for an enormous red velvet curtain that covers the north wall. A pull-rope on one side of the curtain allows it to be drawn back. Behind the curtain hangs a large abstract painting that depicts Halaster surrounded by fields of bloody mouths and people feasting on each other. Worked into the background are various other bizarre figures from beyond the Material Plane. Halaster's face is chillingly calm despite the violent chaos around him, and his piercing gaze seems to follow anyone who views the portrait.

Any creature that beholds the painting ha de salvar per Saviesa (CD 17). Si falla, suffer a random form of long-term madness, determined by rolling on the Long-Term Madness table in {@book chapter 8|DMG|8|Madness Effects} of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}. Si falla, a creature can be affected by the painting again, but not until its current madness ends.

entries.name: 6. Reading Niche

entries: {@b Desks}. In the middle of the room stands a row of desks. Seated behind one of the desks is Spite Harrowdale (NE male Rashemi human {@creature archmage} who speaks Abyssal, Common, Nannès, Èlfic, Giant, and Primordial). His {@creature oni} bodyguard, disguised as a half-ogre named Dumara, stands beside him.
{@b Bookshelves}. Tall bookshelves packed with soft-covered notebooks line the northeast and southwest walls. The books are organized by topic.
{@b Pneumatic Tubes}. A row of ten pneumatic tubes is fastened to the back wall. Beneath the tubes is a shelf of empty copper canisters.

Spite is holding a wand with a {@spell llum} cantrip cast on the end of it and reading a bone-dry biography of Ahghairon, the archwizard who founded Waterdeep. If the characters are being led through Dweomercore by the headmaster, Spite smiles at them as they pass by. Once they're gone, he and the oni cast {@spell invisibility} on themselves and follow the characters, curious to learn their intentions in Dweomercore. Spite and Dumara confront the characters as soon as they can do so privately (see "{@area Evil Students|4a9|x}").

The notebooks stored here are small and thin enough that they can be curled up and stuffed in pneumatic tube canisters. The books cover subjects of interest to wizards, including spell component harvesting, ruminations on the Weave, biographies of famous wizards and liches, tips for creating realistic illusions, and essays written by previous students on a wide range of arcane topics. Any book in this collection that is removed from Dweomercore magically disappears and reappears back on its proper shelf.

entries.name: Pneumatic Tubes
entries: The tubes connect to the students' dormitories ({@area areas 8|4c3|x} and {@area 11|4cd}). From left to right, the tubes are labeled "Turbulence" ({@area area 8a|4c5|x}), "Violence" ({@area area 8b|4c7|x}), "Karstis" ({@area area 8c|4c9|x}), "Yarek" ({@area area 8d|4ca|x}), "Spite" ({@area area 11a|4cf|x}), "Skrianna" ({@area area 11b|4d1|x}), "Vacant" ({@area area 11c|4d4|x}), "Cephalossk" ({@area area 11d|4d5|x}), "Elan" ({@area area 11e|4d7|x}), and "Nylas" ({@area area 11f|4da|x}).

entries.name: 7. Workroom
entries: The door to this room is slightly ajar. Peering out from within is Cephalossk, the {@creature mind flayer arcanist}. It has been too long since the mind flayer has fed on a fresh brain, but it's willing to forgo attacking the characters if they promise to help it feed on Spite's mind instead (see "{@area Cephalossk the Mind Flayer|4ab|x}").
This workroom is filled with tables, braziers, and an assortment of alchemical equipment.

entries.name: 8. Student Dormitories
entries: Each room contains identical furnishings:

{@b Pneumatic Tubes}. A row of five pneumatic tubes is attached to one wall. These tubes are labeled with their destinations and connect to the reading niche ({@area area 6|4bf|x}), the headmaster's office ({@area area 15a|4e7|x}), Wormriddle's workshop ({@area area 23c|506|x}), the kitchen ({@area area 27a|512|x}), and the study hall ({@area area 39|531|x}).

{@b Bed and Footlocker}. Against the far wall rests a plain bed and an iron-banded footlocker with a sturdy padlock that can be picked by using thieves' tools and making a successful DC 20 Destresa check. (If a room is vacant, its key is in the lock; otherwise, a room's key is in the possession of the room's resident.)

{@b Desk}. A plain desk contains quill pens, jars of ink, blank scrolls, notes, notebooks, and {@dice 1d6} empty copper scroll canisters designed to fit inside the pneumatic tubes. Hanging on the wall above the desk is a framed portrait of Halaster. (The portraits in different rooms have different expressions.)

entries.name: 8a. Turbulence's Room
entries: A small hole has been bored through the east wall, enabling Turbulence to converse with her sister in area 8b while the two are in their quarters.

entries.name: Tresor
entries: Turbulence's footlocker contains a set of traveler's clothes and a pentacle-shaped bloodstone amulet (125 gp).

entries.name: 8b. Violence's Room
entries: A small hole has been bored through the west wall, enabling Violence to converse with her sister in area 8a while the two are in their quarters. Violence has drawn a large, sweeping black mustache on the portrait of Halaster above her desk.

entries.name: Tresor
entries: Violence's footlocker contains a set of traveler's clothes, a red leather pouch containing 75 gp, and a spellbook stolen from Yarek's room (area 8d). The book contains these spells: {@spell núvol de dagues}, {@spell convocar elemental}, {@spell visió de foscor}, {@spell núvol de boira}, {@spell greix}, {@spell ràfega de vent}, {@spell Barraca Diminuta d'en Leomund}, {@spell missil màgic}, {@spell Gos Lleial d'en Mordenkainen}, {@spell encàrrec}, {@spell núvol fètid}, i {@spell servent invisible}.

entries.name: 8c. Karstis's Room
entries: This room is set aside for a student named Karstis, whom characters might have encountered on {@adventure level 8|WDMM|8}. If he fled Slitherswamp, Karstis is lying in his bed and reading his spellbook (assuming he still has it). The room is unoccupied otherwise.

entries.name: 8d. Yarek's Room
entries: Yarek was the student responsible for releasing the diable d'ossos in {@area area 47|548|x}. His room hasn't been cleaned out since his demise.

After Yarek died, the Horned Sisters picked through his footlocker and took anything they considered valuable. They left behind a crystal wand (an arcane focus worth 10 gp), a set of fine clothes, and a small, autographed painting of a suave, dark-haired human wizard with a dove perched on his shoulder. The picture is inscribed, "Yarek—Have a magical day! Your friend, Jim."

entries.name: 9. Refuse Pit
entries: A trashy odor fills this room. A 30-foot-long, 10-foot-wide, 60-foot-deep pit in the middle of the floor is filled with refuse and failed experiments to a depth of 10 feet. The chemical mixture has spawned a toxic slime.

Any creature knocked into the pit falls 60 feet onto the soft pile of trash, taking {@dice 1d4} de dany contundent per 10 feet fallen. In addition, a creature that lands in the toxic slime takes 10 ({@dice 3d6}) de dany de verí a l'inici de cada torn seu until the slime is washed off with water or alcohol. A character can determine how to clean off the slime with a successful DC 10 Intel·ligència ({@skill Natura}) check.

entries.name: 10. Where's Halaster?
entries: This room is empty except for an enormous red velvet curtain that covers the northwest wall. A pull-rope on one side of the curtain allows it to be drawn back. Hanging on the wall behind the curtain are fifteen paintings, each one 5 feet long and 3 feet tall, arranged in three rows of five.

Each painting depicts a graduating class of dour-faced Dweomercore wizards. Most of the older paintings show the students as skeletons—signifying which graduating students have died. Careful examination reveals that Halaster appears in every class picture except the center portrait in the middle row. Removing that painting from the wall triggers an elder rune hidden behind it (see "{@area Elder Runes|027|x}"). Determine the rune with a random draw from the Elder Runes Deck (see {@adventure appendix B|WDMM|26}).

entries.name: 11. Student Dormitories
entries: Each room contains identical furnishings:

{@b Pneumatic Tubes}. A row of five pneumatic tubes is attached to one wall. These tubes connect to the reading niche ({@area area 6|4bf|x}), the headmaster's office ({@area area 15a|4e7|x}), Wormriddle's workshop ({@area area 23c|506|x}), the kitchen ({@area area 27a|512|x}), and the study hall ({@area area 39|531|x}).

{@b Bed, Dresser, and Chest}. Against the far wall rests a comfortable bed, a handsome dresser, and a claw-footed iron chest with an {@spell pany arcà} spell cast on it (keyed to the student assigned to the room). A creature can force open the magically locked chest with a successful DC 25 Força ({@skill Atletisme}) check.

{@b Desk}. A beautiful rolltop desk contains quill pens, jars of ink, blank scrolls, notes, notebooks, and {@dice 1d6} empty copper scroll canisters designed to fit inside the pneumatic tubes. Hanging on the wall above the desk is a framed portrait of Halaster. (The portraits in different rooms have different expressions.)

entries.name: 11a. Spite's Room
entries: Spite Harrowdale and his oni bodyguard share this room. Spite has taken the precaution of casting a {@spell glif de guarda} spell on the door frame, set to trigger if anyone other than he or Dumara crosses the threshold. The glyph can't be seen from outside the room. It erupts with magical energy that fills a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on it. Tota criatura dins de l'àrea ha de salvar per Destresa (CD 17), taking 45 ({@dice 10d8}) de dany de tro on a failed saving throw; si supera, en rep la meitat.

entries.name: Tresor
entries: Spite keeps a tiny jeweled chest inside his rolltop desk. This chest (50 gp) is a replica of a full-sized chest made of exquisite materials. The larger chest (5,000 gp) is hidden on the Pla Etèri by means of a {@i Cofre Secret d'en Leomund} spell.

A character can recognize the miniature chest for what it is with a successful DC 15 Intel·ligència ({@skill Arcana}) check. Spite alone can use the replica to recall the larger chest, which contains two spellbooks titled {@i Spells of Spite}, volumes I and II. These books contain all the spells Spite has prepared, plus the following spells: {@spell pany arcà}, {@spell Mà d'en Bigby}, {@spell desintegrar}, {@spell gàbia de força}, {@spell forma gasosa}, {@spell glif de guarda}, {@spell Cofre Secret d'en Leomund}, {@spell laberint}, {@spell Fletxa Àcida d'en Melf}, {@spell Santuari Privat d'en Mordenkainen}, {@spell Dansa Irresistible de l'Otto}, {@spell Riure Horrible de la Tasha}, {@spell Telequinesi}, {@spell Disc Flotant d'en Tenser}, i {@spell polimorfia veritable}.

entries.name: 11b. Skrianna's Room
entries: Skrianna has filled her quarters with creature comforts, including silk bedsheets, soft furs from exotic beasts, a bowl of fresh fruit, a censer of burning incense, and a cushioned wicker reading chair.

entries.name: Skrianna's Diary
entries: Skrianna keeps a diary in her desk. The book affords a rare glimpse into the insane mind of a Shadowdusk family member. In addition to expressing contempt for her peers in Dweomercore, Skrianna rails against the constraints placed on her by the headmaster. She also speaks of an imaginary lover named Acamar, who comes from the void beyond the sky, and talks about visits to the Far Realm in her dreams. She makes a passing reference to other family members, namely Zalthar and Dezmyr, who dwell in Shadowdusk Hold (see {@adventure level 22|WDMM|22}) and plan to return to Waterdeep in force, aided by some kind of giant construct that Halaster is building in Arcturiadoom ({@adventure level 14|WDMM|14}).

entries.name: Tresor
entries: Skrianna's dresser contains ten sets of fine clothes and a set of traveler's clothes. Her chest, which has a mirror attached to the inside of the lid, contains an intricately engraved wand of dark wood, a kit de metzines, and a vial of exquisite perfume (75 gp).

entries.name: 11c. Vacant Room
entries: This room is unoccupied.

entries.name: 11d. Cephalossk's Room
entries: The rolltop desk in this room contains sixteen cloudy jars with preserved humanoid brains in them. The footlocker holds nine similar jars, all empty. Cephalossk hungers for fresh brains but subsists on preserved ones when no other food source is available.

entries.name: Tresor
entries: Cephalossk keeps its spellbook in a desk drawer. The book is made of thin copper plates held together with mitrall wire. Each page bears embossed stanzas of braille-like writing called Qualith, which the mind flayer reads with its tentacles. A non-illithid must use a {@spell comprendre idiomes} spell or similar magic to comprehend the writing. The book contains all the spells Cephalossk has prepared (see the sidebar in the "{@creature Mind Flayer}" entry in the {@book Monster Manual|MM}).

entries.name: 11e. Elan's Room

entries: {@b Familiar}. Elan's familiar, a black {@creature spider} with blood-red markings, clings to the wall above the door and telepathically alerts the drow mage if it detects intruders in the room.
{@b Shrine}. A small shrine dedicated to the demon queen Lolth rests atop a nightstand by the bed.

After being alerted to the arrival of visitors by his spider familiar, Elan spends 3 rounds traveling from {@area area 13a|4de|x} to his dormitory. Elan greets strangers in a friendly manner (see "{@area Elan Tanor'thal|4b0|x}").

The shrine almost resembles a lantern, designed to be easily transportable. Contained inside is a black basalt statuette of Lolth in her drow form, strung with cobwebs. A {@spell detectar màgia} spell reveals an aura of enchantment magic around the statuette. Any creature that touches the statuette ha de salvar per Saviesa (CD 17). Si falla, suffer a random form of short-term madness, determined by rolling on the Short-Term Madness table in {@book chapter 8|DMG|8|Madness Effects} of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}. A creature that successfully saves against the madness effect can safely hold the statuette.

entries.name: Tresor
entries: Elan's chest contains a set of black traveler's clothes, a spider silk pouch containing 38 pp, and a black cloak with a cowl. Pinned to the cloak is an obsidian scarab engraved with the insignia of House Tanor'thal (25 gp).

entries.name: 11f. Nylas's Room
entries: A vile stench issues from an {@creature ogre zombie} that stands against the wall opposite the door. Its orders are to defend Nylas while he is asleep in the room and to protect the Red Wizard's spellbook (see "Treasure" below).

entries.name: Tresor
entries: Nylas hides his spellbook inside the ogre zombie's rotting torso. Characters who have a passive Saviesa ({@skill Percepció}) score of 15 or higher and come within 5 feet of the zombie can see the spellbook wedged between its ribs. A character can use an action to try to snatch the spellbook while the zombie is animate with a successful DC 12 Destresa ({@skill Joc de Mans}) check. No check is needed to remove the book if the zombie is {@condition incapacitat} or destroyed.

Nylas's spellbook has covers carved from coffin wood, pages made of stitched humanoid flesh, and words written in the Red Wizard's own blood. It contains all the spells Nylas has prepared (see the {@creature mage} stat block), plus {@spell animar els morts}, {@spell plaga}, i {@spell contactar plà forani}.

entries.name: 12. Communal Showers
entries: This room contains five shower stalls with iron faucets and shower heads protruding from the walls. Water is channeled here from an underground reservoir and heated by magic, quickly filling the room with steam if the faucets are turned on.

entries.name: 13. Recreation Room
entries: Students come here to relax and recuperate between lessons.

entries.name: 13a. Taproom
entries: This room resembles a comfortable taproom in Waterdeep. The bar is stocked with bottles of fine liquor and casks of wine, and a wooden dartboard is mounted on the west wall with darts carved to look like stirges.

A {@creature drow mage} named Elan Tanor'thal (see "{@area Elan Tanor'thal|4b0|x}") is seated at a table strewn with parchment in the southwest corner, facing the north door. Elan recently acquired a {@item spell pergamí} of {@spell recordar llegendes} from Wormriddle the night hag and is carefully copying the spell from the scroll to his spellbook. He greets intruders in a friendly manner and suggests they partake of the wine while he finishes his work. The scroll turns to dust once the work is complete.

entries.name: Tresor
entries: Elan's black leather-covered spellbook contains all the spells he has prepared plus the following: {@spell confusió}, {@spell contraconjur}, {@spell fabricar}, {@spell descens de ploma}, {@spell glif de guarda}, {@spell arma màgica}, {@spell aparentar}, i {@spell water breathing}. If his attempt to copy Wormriddle's {@item spell pergamí} was successful, Elan's book also contains {@spell recordar llegendes}.

entries.name: 13b. Arch Gate to Level 6

entries: {@b Arch}. Embedded in the south wall is a stone arch bearing images of beholders, flumphs, and stirges (see "Arch Gate" below).
{@b Guard}. An {@condition invisible} {@creature nycaloth} stands against the south wall, protecting the arch gate. The nycaloth becomes visible when it attacks or casts a spell.

The nycaloth's orders are to prevent anyone from using the arch gate to leave Dweomercore without the arcanaloth's permission, and to haul any creature that enters the room by way of the gate to the headmaster's office ({@area area 15a|4e7|x}) for questioning. Given strict instructions not to kill anyone, the nycaloth knocks creatures {@condition inconscient} instead of killing them, then drags them to the headmaster's office.

entries.name: Arch Gate
entries: The arch is one of Halaster's magic gates (see "{@area Gates|028|x}"). Its rules are as follows:

items: If a creature flies or levitates within 5 feet of the arch, the gate opens durant 1 minut.

Characters must be 9th level or higher to pass through this gate (see "{@area Jhesiyra Kestellharp|016|x}"). The first creature to pass through the gate triggers an elder rune (see "{@area Elder Runes|027|x}").
A creature that passes through the gate appears in {@area area 8b on level 6|33b|x}, in the closest unoccupied space next to the identical gate located there.

entries.name: 14. Detention Hall
entries: There's a {@chance 50|50 percent} chance that a red-robed tiefling {@creature mage} named Violence (see "{@area The Horned Sisters|4af|x}") is here, serving a detention for threatening a guest lecturer. The area contains the following:
{@b Desk}. A plain desk is situated against the west wall. If Violence is here, she's seated in the chair, facing the wall, reading a scorched spellbook.
{@b Door Plaque}. The northeast door bears a bronze plaque that reads, "Headmaster's Office—Knock Please."

Violence isn't permitted to leave this hall until the headmaster releases her, and she's unwilling to sneak off and face greater punishment. If the characters approach her in a friendly manner, Violence tells them to leave before the headmaster returns, and recommends that they speak to Turbulence, her sister, who's in the Spellcasting Hall ({@area area 17|4f0|x}).

entries.name: Tresor
entries: Violence's scorched spellbook contains all the spells she has prepared, plus the following: {@spell ego alteració}, {@spell núvol de dagues}, {@spell senefes hipnòtiques}, i {@spell paret de foc}.

entries.name: 15. Arcanaloth's Sanctum
entries: These private chambers belong to the arcanaloth headmaster posing as Halaster Blackcloak.

entries.name: 15a. Headmaster's Office
entries: If it has not already been encountered elsewhere, the {@creature arcanaloth} headmaster is here in its Halaster disguise. The room has a 30-foot-high domed ceiling and the following features:

{@b Statue}. Opposite the door, a life-size statue of Halaster stands atop a 3-foot-high granite pedestal. Dozens of eyes are carved into the wizard's robe, and he holds a stone staff topped with a flickering magical flame (created by a {@spell foc perenne} spell).
{@b Desk}. Resting before the statue is a tremendous oak desk, behind which stands a high-backed chair carved with screaming faces (see below).
{@b Pneumatic Tubes}. Fifteen copper pneumatic tubes span the northwest wall, with a shelf of empty copper canisters below them.
{@b Secret Door}. A secret door opens into {@area area 15b|4ea|x}.

If present, the arcanaloth is writing individual assignments on scrolls and using the pneumatic tube system to deliver them to the academy's students. The assignments involve reading books, completing experiments, and drafting essays on various arcane topics.

The headmaster's chair has an {@spell antipatia/simpatia} spell cast on it. Any creature not able to cast one or more spells of 7th level or higher is subject to the spell's antipathy effect (save DC 17), overwhelmed by screams that seem to emanate from the chair.

entries.name: Pneumatic Tubes
entries: The tubes connect to various other locations in Dweomercore and in Muiral's Gauntlet (level 10). From left to right, the tubes are labeled with their destinations: "Turbulence" ({@area area 8a|4c5|x}), "Violence" ({@area area 8b|4c7|x}), "Karstis" ({@area area 8c|4c9|x}), "Yarek" ({@area area 8d|4ca|x}), "Spite" ({@area area 11a|4cf|x}), "Skrianna" ({@area area 11b|4d1|x}), "Vacant" ({@area area 11c|4d4|x}), "Cephalossk" ({@area area 11d|4d5|x}), "Elan" ({@area area 11e|4d7|x}), "Nylas" ({@area area 11f|4da|x}), "Wormriddle" ({@area area 23c|506|x}), "Kitchen" ({@area area 27a|512|x}), "Study Hall" ({@area area 39|531|x}), "Guest Lecturer" ({@area area 42|537|x}), and "Muiral" ({@area level 10, area 4b|56a|x}).

entries.name: 15b. Arcanaloth's Lair

entries: {@b Bookshelves}. Books are packed into stone shelves that circle the room to a height of 10 feet.

{@b Symbol}. Inscribed on the floor and covered with a circular rug sewn with repeating eye-like patterns is a nearly {@condition invisible}, 10-foot-diameter glyph that serves as the trigger for a {@spell Símbol} spell.

Any creature that is not a fiend triggers the {@spell Símbol} spell when it steps on the circular rug or disturbs the rug in any way. Because the rug covers the spell's triggering glyph, the characters have little chance of spotting the glyph unless they use a {@spell detectar màgia} spell or magic that allows them to see through the rug.
When the glyph triggers, all creatures in this room and area 15a ha de salvar per Constitució (CD 17), taking 55 ({@dice 10d10}) de dany necròtic; si supera, en rep la meitat.

entries.name: Tresor
entries: The arcanaloth is an avid reader and has collected countless books from across the multiverse. Most of the books cover mundane subjects such as etiquette, oratory, and poetry. Twenty of the books are treatises on the Outer Planes and chronicles of historical events on various Material Plane worlds, including Toril, Oerth, Athas, and others; these tomes are worth 100 gp each to an interested buyer. A character who spends 1 hour searching can find one of these rare tomes.

The arcanaloth keeps its spellbook here. The book has leather covers with dreadful images branded into them. The script in the book is {@condition invisible} and can be read only by a creature who has {@sense truesight} or by means of the {@spell veure invisibilitat} spell or similar magic. The book contains all the spells the arcanaloth has prepared, plus {@spell camp antimàgic}, {@spell matanúvol}, {@spell cercle de la mort}, {@spell delayed blast bola de foc}, {@spell tempesta de gel}, {@spell recordar llegendes}, {@spell escodrinyar}, i {@spell Símbol}.

entries.name: 16. Magic Cauldron
entries: {@b Nylas Jowd}. Nylas Jowd, the Thayan {@creature mage} (see "{@area Nylas Jowd|4ad|x}"), lurks in the eastern alcove with his {@condition invisible} companions, two {@creature Will-o'-Wisp||will-o'-wisps}.

{@b Pillars and Cauldron}. Five stone pillars buttress the 20-foot-high ceiling of this hall. A cavity in the southernmost pillar contains a covered lead cauldron visible to anyone south of the pillar. A stained wooden spoon hangs from a hook above the cauldron.

{@b Illusory Wall}. An illusory wall hides area 18. A {@spell detectar màgia} spell cast on the wall reveals an aura of illusion magic. The wall has no substance, and creatures and objects can pass right through it. The wall can be removed with a successful {@spell dissipar màgia} spell (DC 14).

Nylas plans to ambush and kill Turbulence (see {@area area 17|4f0|x}) when she enters the hall to drink from the cauldron. If the characters catch Nylas here, he tries to convince them to kill Turbulence for him and attacks them if they refuse. The will-o'-wisps gang up on the enemy nearest to Nylas, protecting their master.

entries.name: Cauldron
entries: A {@spell detectar màgia} spell can't penetrate the cauldron's lead shell. It weighs 10 pounds and contains {@dice 1d10} doses of a transparent magic liquid that smells and tastes like vinegar. Any creature that drinks a dose of the liquid regains one expended spell slot of any level. If the cauldron is removed from its niche, the magic liquid contained therein turns to ordinary vinegar. The same thing occurs if the vinegar becomes mixed with any other substance. If the empty cauldron is left in the niche, it automatically fills with twelve doses of the magic liquid at the next dawn.

entries.name: 17. Spellcasting Hall
entries: This room has a vaulted ceiling 30 feet high. It is lit by {@spell foc perenne} spells cast on stone wall sconces shaped like fiendish claws. The walls, floor, and ceiling are scorched and pitted from spell damage.

If the characters are visiting the room for the first time, a black-robed female tiefling {@creature mage} named Turbulence (see "{@area The Horned Sisters|4af|x}") is engaged in a spell duel with three archmages, one of whom appears to be Halaster. Turbulence is losing badly and has only 3 hit points remaining. Before the archmages can finish her off, the tiefling shouts, "I surrender!" On their next turns, the archmages retreat into alcoves and become inanimate gray statues (see "Statues" below).

Turbulence tells the characters whatever they want to know about Dweomercore, with the intent of pitting them against Halaster. She mentions that the Mad Mage has a private sanctuary on this level ({@area area 45|53f|x}), hoping they'll try to rob it and create a big enough distraction for her and her sister Violence to escape.

entries.name: Statues
entries: The room's three statues are life-size carvings of robed human wizards. They are used for testing the spellcasting abilities of pupils. A {@spell detectar màgia} spell reveals an aura of transmutation magic around each one:
{@b East Statue}. This statue depicts a young Shou woman whose face is half ruined by acid. She clutches an orb in one hand.
{@b South Statue}. This statue stands atop a stone dais and depicts Halaster Blackcloak in a robe covered with unblinking eyes. He clutches a staff.
{@b West Statue}. This statue depicts a long-haired woman armed with a gnarled wand. She looks out from behind a smooth, featureless mask.

The statues are indestructible in their inanimate state. When a creature moves between the west and east statues, all three become flesh and attack all other creatures in the room. Roll initiative for each statue separately. While animated, the statues are {@creature Archmage||archmages}, with these changes:

items: The statues are unaligned constructs that speak only when casting spells that have verbal components. They can't leave the room.
They have the {@spell tempesta de gel} spell prepared instead of {@spell banishment}, and the {@spell dit de la mort} spell prepared instead of {@spell teleportació}.

If {@condition incapacitat} or reduced to 0 hit points, a statue instantly teleports to its alcove, where it reverts to its inanimate form and regains all its hit points. It can't reanimate again until all three archmages have reverted to statues.

The statues return to their alcoves, revert to their inanimate forms, and regain all their hit points if, when their turn comes up, no other creatures remain in the room that aren't {@condition incapacitat}. This also happens if a creature in the room speaks the words "I surrender!" in any language.
Any creature reduced to 0 hit points by an animated statue is stable and {@condition inconscient}.

entries: The first time the adventurers defeat a particular animated archmage statue, they receive PX for it as with any creature defeated in combat. Subsequent victories against that statue don't provide more PX, however.

entries.name: Tresor
entries: Turbulence carries a soot-stained spellbook containing all the spells she has prepared, plus the following: {@spell ego alteració}, {@spell núvol de dagues}, {@spell senefes hipnòtiques}, i {@spell paret de foc}.

entries.name: 18. Illusory Walls
entries: This 10-foot-high hallway is closed off to the west and east by illusory walls. A {@spell detectar màgia} spell reveals that the walls are illusions without substance, and creatures and objects can pass right through them. An illusory wall can be removed with a successful {@spell dissipar màgia} spell (DC 14).

entries.name: 19. Ghostly Adventurer

entries: {@b Apparition}. At the east end of this hall, the faint apparition of a human adventurer appears to be painstakingly searching the walls for secret doors.
{@b Walls}. The walls bear mosaics that have been chipped away and damaged beyond recognition or repair. The wall to the west is illusory (see {@area area 18|4f4|x}).
{@b Trophy Case}. Between the doors leading to area 20 stands an empty wooden trophy case.

The apparition is a regional effect created by the Mad Mage (see "{@area Halaster's Lair|bb9|x}"). It resembles a young human woman, dressed in well-worn adventurer's clothes. It can't be harmed, and it doesn't acknowledge creatures or objects in any way.

entries.name: 20. Lecture Hall
entries: This sloped lecture hall has a 15-foot-high ceiling and the following features:
{@b Light}. Stone sconces protruding from the walls have {@spell foc perenne} spells cast on them.
{@b Benches}. The northern half of the room contains raised stone benches for students.

{@b Dais}. To the south, a large chalkboard is mounted above a 5-foot-high stone dais. Drawn on the chalkboard are three frog-like bipeds with wide, toothy smiles. They are arranged in a triangular formation; the top one is drawn in red chalk, the bottom left in blue, and the bottom right in green.

{@b Gurneys}. Two stone gurneys are parked in the room. Strapped to one table is the corpse of a quaggoth, its chest burst open and entrails consumed. The other table, draped in a floor-length black sheet, has a {@creature slaad tadpole} hidden under it (see "Slaad Tadpole" below).

Any character who studies the chalkboard drawings and succeeds on una tirada d'Intel·ligència ({@skill Arcana}) amb CD 15 recognizes them as a red, blue, and green slaad. Yellow chalk arrows point from the red slaad to the other two. Next to each slaad are words written in Abyssal. Any character who reads Abyssal can translate the words:

items: "Parent" is written next to the red slaad.
"Offspring of parent and host" is written next to the blue slaad.
"Offspring if host is spellcaster" is written next to the green slaad.

entries.name: Slaad Tadpole
entries: Wormriddle the night hag prepared a special demonstration for students by implanting a captured quaggoth with a red slaad egg pellet. Unfortunately for her, the slaad tadpole has hatched sooner than expected. The night hag hasn't checked on her subject recently and doesn't know the tadpole is loose. The tadpole attacks the first humanoid that approaches within 5 feet of it. Left alone, the tadpole grows into a {@creature blue slaad} after {@dice 1d12} hours. Characters who enroll in the academy might be tasked with eradicating it for Wormriddle.

entries.name: 21. Classrooms
entries: These classrooms offer a more intimate learning environment than the lecture hall.
{@b Chalkboard}. A blank chalkboard mounted on the west wall has a narrow stone shelf under it for catching chalk dust. Niches under the chalkboard hold brushes and sticks of colored chalk.

{@b Desks}. Facing the chalkboard are twelve desks, in three rows of four. Each desk has cast-iron legs, a sculpted copper seat, and a wooden writing surface gouged with graffiti in various languages.
{@b Hooks}. The back wall has a row of stone hooks for hanging cloaks.

entries.name: 21b. South Classroom
entries: This room is identical to area 21a, except that someone has hastily scrawled the following words on the chalkboard in Common: "Wizards of Yore class canceled. Research Ahghairon circa 1071 DR. Expect a quiz!"

Any character who succeeds on una tirada d'Intel·ligència ({@skill Història}) amb CD 20 recalls that 1071 DR, the Year of Lion's Roars, was the year in which the archmage Ahghairon, first Lord of Waterdeep, created magic wards to protect his city against marauding dragons.

entries.name: 22. Potion Brewery

entries: {@b Odor}. This chamber reeks of chemical admixtures.
{@b Furnishings}. Arranged in the northern half of the room are a dozen fat stone cauldrons and cupboards full of ingredients in jars.

{@b Stone Basin}. The southern half of the room is taken up by a 20-foot-wide, 5-foot-deep, bowl-shaped stone basin enclosed by a 3-foot-high retaining wall. Filling the basin is a toxic brew containing two poison weirds (see "Toxic Brew" below).
The cauldrons are used by students for brewing potions. A valve at the base of each cauldron opens a natural gas vent underneath it, and a flint pedal ignites the gas to heat the cauldron.

The cupboards contain nearly five hundred jars of ingredients used to brew common and uncommon magic potions, as well as other alchemical concoctions. Each jar is labeled in Abyssal. The ingredients are inert and not particularly valuable on their own.

entries.name: Toxic Brew
entries: Failed potions are tossed into the stone basin, adding to the toxic brew within. Any creature that starts its turn immersed in the brew is {@condition emmetzinat} until it leaves the liquid and washes itself off with water.

Two poison weirds lurk in the toxic brew and try to grapple creatures within reach and pull them into the basin. These creatures are {@creature Aigüextranya||aigüextranyes} with a challenge rating of 4 (1,100 PX) and these changes:

items: The weirds are {@condition invisible} while fully immersed in the toxic brew. They die if forced to leave the basin or if a {@spell purificar menjar i beure} spell is cast on the toxic brew.
A creature takes 10 ({@dice 3d6}) de dany de verí a l'inici de cada torn seu while {@condition grappled} by a poison weird.

entries.name: 23. Wormriddle's Sanctum
entries: These chambers are claimed by Wormriddle the night hag (see "{@area Wormriddle the Night Hag|4a8|x}"). If she hasn't already been encountered and defeated elsewhere, there's a {@chance 50|50 percent} chance she's in {@area area 23b|503|x}. Otherwise, she's in {@area area 23c|506|x}.

The hag's {@spell saltar de pla} spell doesn't work in Undermountain, but she can use her {@i heartstone} to escape to the Pla Etèri if outmatched. The flesh gòlems in {@area area 23c|506|x} form Wormriddle's first line of defense. If they're defeated, the hag seeks out the headmaster, who directs the hag to round up the students and form a posse to hunt down and destroy the interlopers.

entries.name: 23a. Smoke-Filled Hall
entries: This chamber is heavily obscured by smoke billowing out of two stone braziers. The night hag uses the smoke to deter students from entering her sanctum. The smoke blocks vision entirely, and creatures in the smoke are effectively {@condition encegat}. Each brazier bowl contains dozens of tiny holes through which the smoke seeps. Liquid poured into a brazier drains away quickly and does nothing to stop the billowing smoke.

Wormriddle fashioned tight-fitting iron lids for the braziers and keeps them in area 23b. If both braziers are properly covered, the smoke in the room begins to dissipate, making the area lightly obscured after 1 minute and clear after 5 minutes.

entries.name: 23b. Wormriddle's Den
entries: If Wormriddle the {@creature night hag} is here and has been alerted to the presence of intruders, she assumes the form of a young halfling girl named Medley. In this form, she wears a black witch's hat and sweeps the floor with a small twig broom. The hag's den has these features:
{@b Bones}. Cat bones cover the floor.
{@b Iron Lids}. Leaning against the north wall are a pair of 25-pound, circular iron lids (covers for the braziers in {@area area 23a|502|x}).

{@b Bed}. Mummified cats hang from a decrepit four-poster bed near the south wall. (Tucked under a moldy pillow is a jar filled with the night hag's dirty toenail clippings, which the hag uses to weave evil magic.)
{@b Dolls}. Behind the bed, mounted to the wall, is a shelf lined with eight dolls. A ninth doll has fallen off the shelf and onto the floor.

In her halfling form, Wormriddle claims to be one of Dweomercore's most promising students and offers to take characters on a tour. If the characters accept, she leads them to {@area area 23c|506|x} and orders her gòlems to attack. If the gòlems have already been defeated, the hag weeps over their loss and turns ethereal to escape the party, only to return once she rounds up the students and forms a posse. If the characters attack her here, the night hag turns ethereal and flees.

entries.name: Doll Collection
entries: The dolls are crudely fashioned in the likenesses of the students currently enrolled in Dweomercore. The eight on the shelf represent Spite, Cephalossk, Nylas, Skrianna, the Horned Sisters, Elan, and Karstis. The doll on the floor represents Yarek, the student recently killed by the diable d'ossos in {@area area 48|54e|x}. Each doll incorporates bits of the student's hair or some other sample from its body (foul-smelling slime in the case of Cephalossk the mind flayer).
