entries.name: {@item Dodecahedron of Doom|WDMM}
entries: A rare wondrous item, this twelve-sided metal die is 12 inches across and bears the numbers 1 through 12 engraved on its pentagonal sides. The dodecahedron contains arcane clockwork mechanisms that whir and click whenever the die is cast.

The dodecahedron can be hurled up to 60 feet as an action. A random magical effect occurs when the die comes to rest after rolling across the ground for at least 10 feet. If an effect requires a target and no eligible target is within range, nothing happens. Spells cast by the dodecahedron require no components. Roll a {@dice d12} and consult the following table to determine the effect:

rows: The dodecahedron explodes and is destroyed. Each creature within 20 feet of the exploding die ha de salvar per Destresa (CD 13), taking 40 ({@dice 9d8}) de dany de força; si supera, en rep la meitat.
The dodecahedron casts {@spell llum} on itself. The effect lasts until a creature touches the die.
The dodecahedron casts {@spell ray of frost} (+5 a impactar), targeting a random creature within 60 feet of it that doesn't have total cover against the attack.
The dodecahedron casts {@spell braó electritzant} (+5 a impactar) on the next creature that touches it.
The dodecahedron casts {@spell darkness} on itself. The effect has a duration of 10 minutes.
The next creature to touch the dodecahedron gains {@dice 1d10} punts de vida temporals that last durant 1 hora.

entries.name: {@item Orb of Gonging|WDMM}
entries: This common wondrous item is a hollow, 5-inch-diameter orb that weighs 5 pounds. Its outer shell is composed of notched bronze rings, which can be turned so that the notches line up. Aligning the notches requires an action, and doing so causes the orb to gong loudly until the notches are no longer aligned. The sounds are spaced 6 seconds apart and can be heard out to a range of 600 feet.

entries.name: 4. Pretty Big Hate Machine
entries: Trobriand uses this 50-foot-high cavern as a testing area for his most dangerous projects.
{@b Wreckage}. The cavern is charred from numerous fires and explosions. The broken remains of a scaladar and smaller, unidentifiable constructs litter the floor.
{@b Shockerstomper}. Not visible from the cavern entrance is a Gargantuan contraption made of wood, metal, and stone. It looms in the northeastern alcove.

Shockerstomper consists of a 30-foot-diameter, saucer-shaped platform mounted atop seven mechanical legs. Crowning the platform are three spherical turrets, each with a brass nozzle. The entire construction stands 20 feet tall. The control module is a chamber obscured from view in the center of the contraption, nestled between the three turrets.

Shockerstomper has {@sense visió a cegues} out to a range of 60 feet and is blind beyond this radius. It activates when a creature comes within 60 feet of it. Once it is activated, Shockerstomper attempts to destroy all creatures in the cavern. It can't pursue creatures beyond the cavern, because it's too big to fit through the exit. The characters earn 11,500 PX for disabling or defeating it.

Shockerstomper is a Gargantuan construct with immunity to poison and psychic damage, as well as the {@condition encegat}, {@condition eixordat}, {@condition fascinat}, {@condition acovardit}, {@condition paralitzat}, i {@condition emmetzinat} conditions. It has a walking speed of 40 feet. Its main body (saucer and turrets) has AC 18 and 300 hit points. Its legs can be attacked separately; each leg has AC 20 and 50 hit points. When a leg es queda a 0 punts de vida, it is disabled, and Shockerstomper can use a reaction to detach it from its main body. Whenever one of its legs is disabled, Shockerstomper's walking speed is reduced by 10 feet. The whole contraption topples over and shuts down if four of its seven legs are disabled.
Shockerstomper's ability scores are as follows: Força 23, Destresa 10, Constitució 20, Intel·ligència 1, Saviesa 1, Carisma 1.

entries.name: Electrified Surface
entries: A creature that ends its turn in contact with Shockerstomper's body (saucer or turrets) ha de salvar per Constitució (CD 15), taking 22 ({@dice 4d10}) de dany elèctric; si supera, en rep la meitat.

entries.name: Forma Immutable
entries: Shockerstomper és immune a tot conjur o efecte que vulgui alterar-li la forma.

entries.name: Multi-atac
entries: Shockerstomper makes three Lightning Turret attacks and two Stomp attacks.

entries.name: Lightning Turret
entries: The turret shoots a magical lightning bolt at one creature within 60 feet of Shockerstomper. The target ha de salvar per Destresa (CD 15), taking 44 ({@dice 8d10}) de dany elèctric; si supera, en rep la meitat.

entries.name: Esclafar
entries: {@i Atac armat cos a cos}: +8 a impactar, 10 peus d'abast, una criatura. {@i Hit}: 22 ({@dice 3d10 + 6}) de dany contundent.

entries.name: Countermeasures
entries: Shockerstomper and its elements can be disabled or destroyed in the following ways.

{@b Control Module}. A creature atop or above Shockerstomper's platform can locate its control module with a successful DC 15 Intel·ligència ({@skill Investigació}) check or Saviesa ({@skill Percepció}) check. Com a acció, a character can try to open the control module's access panel, either by tearing it off with a successful DC 25 Força ({@skill Atletisme}) check or by dislodging it with thieves' tools and a successful DC 25 Destresa check. Behind the panel, embedded in the floor of the control module, is a 5-foot-diameter pulsating crystal hemisphere with AC 10, 25 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage. Destroying the crystal hemisphere shuts down Shockerstomper.

{@b Lightning Turret}. A character can try to plug the nozzle of a lightning turret with a 10-pound rock or similar object, doing so with a successful DC 15 Força ({@skill Atletisme}) check. A plugged turret can't shoot lightning until a creature uses an action to try to clear the obstruction, which requires another successful DC 15 Força ({@skill Atletisme}) check. Shockerstomper has no ability to clear an obstruction itself.

entries.name: 5. Scrap Metal Warren
entries: A 40-foot-high mountain of scrap metal has 10-foot-diameter tunnels winding through it. The scrap metal pile spills into area 2, dominates the cavern north of it, and completely fills the opening between the two caverns.

The outer surface of the scrap pile is terreny difícil. In addition, any creature that tries to climb or walk across the jagged heap of metal must succeed on una tirada de Destresa ({@skill Acrobàcies}) amb CD 15 to avoid triggering a small avalanche that causes it to fall {@condition enderrocat} and take 7 ({@dice 2d6}) de dany perforant.
The entrances to the warren are marked with arrows on map 13. The warren contains the following:
{@b Rust Monsters}. A {@creature rust monster} gorges on scrap metal in each of the squares marked R on the map.

{@b Central Chamber}. In the heart of the warren is a 30-foot-wide, 40-foot-long, 10-foot-high chamber containing four dead hobgoblins. Ten {@creature Lava Child|WDMM|lava children} (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}) hide in the walls and emerge to attack anyone who enters the room.

The rust monsters tend to ignore other creatures that maintain a respectful distance. If a character wearing metal armor or carrying a metal shield walks within 5 feet of a rust monster, there's a {@chance 30|30 percent} chance that the creature attacks the character with the intention of devouring the armor or shield.

The lava children walk through the scrap metal as though it doesn't exist. They regard Zox as a trusted friend and, at his request, attack creatures that enter the central chamber. The lava children pursue fleeing creatures as far as the warren entrances before disappearing back into the scrap metal. While they are hidden in the metal walls, the lava children have total cover.

The hobgoblins were sent to find and kill Zox Clammersham but fell prey to the lava children. A character who examines the corpses and succeeds on una tirada de Saviesa ({@skill Medicina}) amb CD 10 ascertains that the hobgoblins were killed two days ago. A search of the hobgoblin corpses reveals that one has a charcoal sketch of Zox Clammersham on a crumpled-up sheet of parchment.

entries.name: 6. Back Tunnel

entries: {@b Corpses}. Lying against the walls of this 20-foot-high tunnel are the mutilated corpses of ten hobgoblins.
{@b Scaladar}. Three {@creature scaladar|WDMM} (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}) patrol the tunnel.
The scaladar hunt as a trio and have orders from Zox to kill any humanoids they see. Ideally, the characters should encounter the scaladar after they have had time to inspect the hobgoblin corpses.

The hobgoblins were sent to find and kill Zox but fell prey to the scaladar. A character who examines the corpses and succeeds on una tirada de Saviesa ({@skill Medicina}) amb CD 10 can ascertain that the hobgoblins have been dead for about a tenday. Half of them were torn apart by sharp claws, and the rest died from deep, charred puncture wounds.
{@b Ceiling}. This cavern has a 90-foot-high ceiling.
{@b Palace}. Atop a 20-foot-high plateau of twisted scrap metal rises a rambling palace made of jagged metal plates welded together. Circular iron doors are recessed in the walls.
{@b Scrap Pile}. The slopes of the scrap pile are strewn with the mutilated corpses of several rust monsters.

entries.name: Palace Features
entries: The structural features of the palace are summarized here.

entries.name: Ceilings
entries: The ceilings throughout the palace are 20 feet high.

entries.name: Doors
entries: The palace is sealed off by 7-foot-diameter circular doors, each one made of riveted iron plates and fitted with iron handles, iron hinges, and a sturdy iron lock. Each lock is molded to look like a smiling gnome's face missing its nose. Zox carries a stubby iron key with a head shaped like a tiny bulbous nose that unlocks all nine doors. Zox fashioned a spare key but lost it during a recent Undermountain foray (see {@area level 12, area 14|67e|x}).

A character can try to pick a door's lock using thieves' tools, doing so una tirada de Destresa (CD 20). A {@spell picaporta} spell or similar magic also works. A door can be forced open with a successful DC 30 Força ({@skill Atletisme}) check. It can also be destroyed. Each door has AC 19, 40 hit points, a damage threshold of 10, and immunity to poison and psychic damage.

Zox has cast a {@spell glif de guarda} spell on every door. Each glyph is inscribed on the inside of the door so that it can't be detected by anyone outside the palace. The glyph triggers when the door is opened by any means other than using the proper key. When triggered, the glyph erupts with magical energy in a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on it. Tota criatura dins de l'àrea ha de salvar per Destresa (CD 17), taking 31 ({@dice 7d8}) de dany de tro; si supera, en rep la meitat. The sound of a triggered glyph is audible throughout the cavern and the palace. Alerted to the presence of intruders, Zox awaits them in {@area area 7c|6e6|x}.

entries.name: Il·luminació
entries: The palace interior is dark. Zox relies on his {@sense visió de foscor} to see.

entries.name: Walls
entries: The walls of the palace are 10 feet thick and made out of loose scrap piled between inner and outer bulwarks of welded metal. The fortress has no windows, but close examination reveals gaps in the walls that a Tiny creature or a creature in forma gasosa can navigate.

entries.name: 7a. Junk Room
entries: Zox stores curious bits of junk here until he finds creative uses for them. The room's contents are as follows:
{@b Table}. A 2-foot-high, roughly hexagonal table made of welded scrap metal is covered with scavenged bits of broken machinery and scraps of food.
{@b Music}. Tinny music emanates from the southern doorway (leading to {@area area 7c|6e6|x}).

entries.name: 7b. Living Quarters
entries: {@b Pet}. A {@creature giant badger} playfully chews on a stuffed toy in the middle of the room.
{@b Furnishings}. The dingy furnishings include an unmade bed, a drafting table, and an iron safe (see "Iron Safe" below).
{@b Alcoves}. Alcoves to the south contain a poorly draining privy and a modest kitchenette where food molders in unclean pots and filthy pans.
{@b Arch}. Set into the west wall is a stone arch decorated with inlaid images of dancing goblins. Carved into the arch's keystone is the letter D.
The giant badger fights only in self-defense. Characters who use magic to speak with it can learn the following information if they ask it the right questions:

items: Zox is afraid of the "scary red metal wearers" (hobgoblins) and has befriended the "burning men" (azers) and "smileys" (lava children) that live in the surrounding caves. Zox has a bodyguard named Rex.
Zox normally gets food from the nearby fungus forest (see {@area area 12|6f4|x}), but the "scary red metal wearers" recently set the forest on fire.
The combination to Zox's iron safe is "prairie dog, wombat, badger, armadillo, wombat."

entries.name: Arch Gate to Level 6
entries: The arch embedded in the west wall is one of Halaster's magic gates (see "{@area Gates|028|x}"). Its rules are as follows:

items: The gate opens for 1 minute if a creature stands within 5 feet of the arch and either sings a D note or plays a D note on a instrument musical.

Characters must be at least 9th level to pass through this gate (see "{@area Jhesiyra Kestellharp|016|x}"). The first creature to pass through the gate triggers an elder rune (see "{@area Elder Runes|027|x}").
A creature that passes through the gate appears in {@area area 47a on level 6|361|x}, in the closest unoccupied space next to the identical gate located there.

entries.name: Iron Safe
entries: The square iron safe measures 2 feet on a side and weighs 1,000 pounds. It has AC 19, 50 hit points, a damage threshold of 15, and immunity to poison and psychic damage. Instead of numbers, the lock has tiny pictographs of the following burrowing animals: armadillo, badger, chipmunk, gerbil, meerkat, mole, prairie dog, rabbit, tarantula, and wombat.

A character who spends 1 minute with an ear pressed to the safe door can try to pick the safe's combination lock, doing so with a successful DC 25 Destresa ({@skill Percepció}) check. The correct combination is prairie dog, wombat, badger, armadillo, wombat. A {@spell picaporta} spell or similar magic also opens the safe.

entries.name: Tresor
entries: The safe contains ninety 1-pound gold ingots (100 gp each), ten red garnets (100 gp each), a set of {@item Nolzur's marvelous pigments}, and Zox's spellbook, which is missing its cover and has lost a few pages due to adventuring mishaps. The spellbook contains all the spells Zox has prepared plus {@spell animar objectes}, {@spell fabricar}, {@spell glif de guarda}, {@spell botar}, i {@spell truc de la corda}.

entries.name: 7c. Tinker Shop

entries: {@b Tinkerer}. A wild-haired gnome wearing a grease-stained apron over threadbare robes (Zox Clammersham) sits atop the table, using a set of tinker's tools to tune a Tiny music box that is playing a tinny tune.
{@b Guardian}. Rex, a {@creature shield guardian} painted with gold stars and crescent moons, stands next to the table.
{@b Loose Pages}. The floor is strewn with sheets of parchment bearing sketches of metal contraptions (including the Simulacrux in {@area area 2|6bd|x}).

Rex the shield guardian accompanies Zox wherever he goes. Unlike most shield guardians, Rex doesn't have an amulet and thus can't be commanded by another creature. Zox has stored a {@spell invisibilitat superior} spell in the shield guardian.
Zox Clammersham is a rock gnome {@creature archmage}, with these changes:

items: Zox is chaotic good.

He has these racial traits: He speaks Aquan, Auran, Common, Gnomish, Ignan, and Terran. He is Small and has a walking speed of 25 feet. He has {@sense visió de foscor} out to a range of 60 feet. He has advantage on all Intel·ligència, Saviesa, and Carisma saving throws against magic.
He has the {@spell confusió} spell prepared instead of {@spell banishment}.

entries: Zox retired to Trobriand's Graveyard after the rest of his adventuring party fell prey to the perils of Undermountain. Having lost all track of time, he doesn't know how long ago his companions perished or how long he's been by himself. Zox has no interest in joining another adventuring party, preferring to work alone.

Zox carries a key that unlocks the palace doors, and he wears a scaladar control ring on the middle finger of his left hand. This ring allows him to command the scaladar on this level. He never willingly parts with the ring, going so far as to swallow it to prevent its theft. If attacked or threatened, Zox activates the room's ball turrets, then orders his shield guardian to attack.

Zox's music box has no magical properties beyond its ability to play a tune. The music plays continuously but stops if the box is dropped, shaken, or otherwise handled roughly. The box is a Tiny object with AC 10, 1 hit point, and immunity to poison and psychic damage. Provided it has 1 hit point, the box can be repaired with tinker's tools. Repairing it requires 10 minutes and a successful DC 15 Destresa check, whereupon the music resumes playing.

Zox plans to use the Simulacrux (see {@area area 2a|6be|x}) to create enough scaladar to build new things and comfortably control what he now views as his domain. The biggest obstacles to his success are the hobgoblins that keep stealing his scrap metal.

entries.name: 8. Smithy
entries: Zox has convinced the creatures living in this cavern that he is Trobriand's apprentice and thus deserves their cooperation. The 90-foot-high, soot-stained cavern contains the following:
{@b Forges}. Intense heat and thick smoke billow from five forges protruding from the cavern walls, their fires illuminating the cave. An {@creature àzer} smith stands at each forge.
{@b Scrap Pile}. A 20-foot-high pile of scrap metal dominates the middle of the cavern. Hiding in it are nine {@creature Lava Child|WDMM|lava children} (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}).

Runes carved on the inside walls of the forge channel magical energy from the Elemental Plane of Fire. Destroying a forge causes it to stop generating fire and heat. Each forge has AC 17, 80 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage.

entries.name: Azers
entries: Els azers were brought here from the Elemental Plane of Fire by Trobriand to sculpt metal into desired shapes. Posing as Trobriand's apprentice, Zox orders els azers to craft parts for the Simulacrux (see {@area area 2a|6be|x}) and his other pet projects. Els azers understand the purpose of the Simulacrux (to replicate scaladar) but are under the false impression that Zox is building it at Trobriand's behest, not for his own ends. Els azers are frustrated by Zox because the gnome is scatterbrained and has them working on multiple projects at once. They strongly dislike the hobgoblins, who rob them of metal.

A character can convince an azer to undertake a new project with a successful DC 19 Carisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check. L'àzer works for free and can craft a functional metal weapon or a metal shield in {@dice 1d6} days, or a functional suit of metal armor in {@dice 3d6} days.
Els azers are nonthreatening. If the lava children attack the party, els azers don't join the fight, preferring to observe from the periphery.

entries.name: Lava Children
entries: Lava children can pass through metal as though it doesn't exist. Those here lurk in the pile of scrap metal, emerging to attack any creature, other than Zox or els azers, that comes within 5 feet of their scrap heap.

entries.name: 9. Metal Pools
entries: This cave has a 30-foot-high ceiling and contains two 10-foot-deep pools of shiny liquid metal drawn from the Elemental Plane of Earth. The western pool holds liquid iron, the eastern pool liquid steel. Despite being liquefied, the metal is cool to the touch. A {@spell detectar màgia} spell reveals a strong aura of transmutation magic emanating from each pool. No matter how much metal is removed from a pool, its depth never changes.

Metal removed from the pool solidifies instantly, becoming as strong and immutable as wrought iron or cold steel. The metal instantly hardens upon leaving the pool and forms a hard coating around anything dipped in it. Prying off the hardened metal coating requires a successful DC 23 Força ({@skill Atletisme}) check.

Those who know how can draw metal from the pools in cube form. A creature might learn the method by casting {@spell identificar} on a pool or by asking Zox. A creature must place one or more of its hands within 1 foot of the pool's surface and recite the following in Terran: {@i agrach taar azlach} (which, loosely translated to Common, means "shape to shapelessness"). This causes a cubic foot of liquid metal to rise out of the pool, harden into a solid 1-foot cube, and hang weightless in the air at the edge of the pool, where anyone can grab it. The act of bringing forth one of these cubes is magically tiring, and a creature that does so gains one level of {@condition exhaust}.
One minute after it hardens, the cube loses its weightlessness. A 1-foot cube of iron or steel weighs 500 pounds.

entries.name: 10. Resting Cave
entries: This 30-foot-high cave has the remains of an adventuring party's campfire in the middle of it and no other features of note.

entries.name: 11. Hobgoblin Base Camp
entries: Hobgoblins have turned this 60-foot-high cavern into a base camp. The camp's leader, the ruthless hobgoblin warlord Yargoth the Breaker, answers to a more powerful warlord named Doomcrown (see {@adventure level 14|WDMM|14}).

entries.name: 11a. Stalactites and Stalagmites

entries: {@b Rock Formations}. Stalactites ranging in height from 10 to 20 feet cling to the cave roof, while stalagmites of similar size thrust up from the floor.

{@b Monsters}. Lurking behind the cluster of stalagmites to the north are five domesticated {@creature Death Dog||death dogs}, four {@creature Hobgoblin||hobgoblins}, and the {@creature hobgoblin warlord} Yargoth the Breaker.

When Yargoth gives the order, she and the death dogs spring into melee combat while the other hobgoblins take cover behind the rock formations and shoot arrows. The hobgoblins in area 11b also join the battle by loading, aiming, and firing the flame canós in that location.

If the characters choose to parley with Yargoth, she suggests they combine forces and storm Zox's fortress. Yargoth knows that the fortress doors are locked and magically trapped, and that Zox is protected by a tall, gòlem-like construct (Rex the shield guardian). Yargoth wants Zox's scaladar control ring for her efforts; if the characters agree to help her, they are free to claim anything else they find in the fortress. Yargoth keeps her end of the deal, provided the characters do the same.

entries.name: 11b. Fire and Rust

entries: {@b Defenses}. Six {@creature Hobgoblin||hobgoblins} stand guard near a pair of flame canós aimed at a natural stone bridge.

{@b Lit Enclosure}. Seven-foot-high stone walls form an enclosure that abuts the west wall. Inside are trapped four {@creature Rust Monster||rust monsters}. Tied to a rope and strung across the top of the enclosure like ornaments are glowing sacs (giant fire beetle glands) that shed orange light as brightly as torches.
{@b Eines}. Leaning against the walls of this enclosure are a pair of 10-foot poles, each with a loop of rope at one end, and a battered wooden tower shield.

When Yargoth gives the order to attack, three hobgoblins acting on the same initiative count load, aim, and fire each of the flame canós. The hobgoblins discovered these siege engines during their initial exploration of Trobriand's Graveyard.

A flame canó is a bulky mechanical contraption that hurls casks of foc alquímic that explode on impact. Before one of these weapons can be fired, it must be loaded and aimed. It takes one action to load the weapon, one action to aim it, and one action to fire it. Each flame canó has three casks of foc alquímic resting next to it.

entries.name: Flame Canó
entries: {@i Atac armat a distància}: +4 a impactar, 60/240 peus d'abast, un objectiu. {@i Hit}: 3 ({@dice 1d6}) de dany contundent mes 17 ({@dice 5d6}) de dany de foc, and the target catches fire. While on fire, l'objectiu rep {@dice 1d6} de dany de foc a l'inici de cada torn seu. A creature can end this damage by immersing itself in water or by using an action to make a successful DC 10 Destresa check to extinguish the flames.

The stone enclosure has a hinged gate made of sturdy wooden poles lashed together with rope and held shut with a simple latch. The hobgoblins like to starve the rust monsters for a few days, then set them loose on this level. The rust monsters can't escape from the pen on their own, but they are drawn to the scent of metal. The hobgoblins use the wooden tower shield and 10-foot poles to wrangle the rust monsters outside their pen and keep the beasts away from their metal armor.
Twelve giant fire beetle glands illuminate the rust monster pen. Each gland is the size of a small loaf of bread and glows for {@dice 1d3} days before going dark.

entries.name: 12. Paradise Lost
entries: These 40-foot-high caverns once housed a thriving fungus forest and a colony of peaceful myconids. The hobgoblins slaughtered the myconids, then burned down the forest. A thin, pungent smoke hangs in the air throughout these caverns.

entries.name: 12a. Southern Forest

entries: {@b Burned Remains}. Blackened and smoldering zurkhwood stalks, their caps destroyed by fire, stand amid the charred remains of what once were neatly tended fungus gardens.

{@b Corpses}. Lying amid the razed mushrooms are the charred corpses of {@dice 1d4} giant fire beetles, {@dice 1d6} myconid sprouts, and {@dice 1d8} myconid adults. The glands have been torn out of the fire beetles' bodies.

A character who inspects the corpses and succeeds on una tirada de Saviesa ({@skill Medicina}) amb CD 15 can determine that the beetles and myconids were killed by slashing weapons and arrows, then burned.

entries.name: 12b. Central Forest
entries: This area contains the same features as {@area area 12a|6f5|x}.

entries.name: 12c. Northern Forest
entries: In addition to features similar to those in {@area area 12a|6f5|x}, the body of an 8-foot-tall {@creature myconid sovereign} lies among the dead—pierced by multiple hobgoblin arrows and burned like the other corpses. If the sovereign is touched, it trembles with life, having stabilized at 0 hit points. If it receives magical healing, it awakens and ejects a cloud of rapport spores so it can communicate with its rescuers. Award the party 450 PX for healing the sovereign.

The myconid sovereign, Chanterella, has a flaring yellow cap and a ruffled yellow body half cooked by fire. It recounts the hobgoblins' horrific attack and mourns the destruction of its colony. In gratitude for helping it, the sovereign gives characters its hidden treasure (see "Treasure" below). Chanterella then urges the characters to seek out Zox if they're looking for allies. The myconid has a high opinion of the gnome.

Chanterella won't leave these caverns. Although its colony has been wiped out, the myconid sovereign wants to try to regrow the fungus forest. After helping the characters as well as it can, it bids them farewell and invites them to return whenever they feel like it.

entries.name: Tresor
entries: A 1-foot-thick, 10-foot-square patch of luminous but soot-blackened purple mold covers the roof of the northern alcove (marked X on map 13). Buried in the mold are two gourds, one containing a {@item potion of diminution} and the other a {@item potion of longevity}. Chanterella grew the purple mold and can silently command it to extrude sticky tendrils, which it uses to lower the potions within easy reach.

Sunlight, any effect that cures disease, or any effect that deals radiant or necrotic damage destroys the mold. If the mold is destroyed while the potions are still hidden in its mass, the potions fall and shatter on the floor. A character in the alcove can use a reaction to try to catch one falling potion, doing so with a successful DC 11 Destresa saving throw.

entries.name: Aftermath
entries: Defeating the hobgoblins calms this level for a tenday. After that, Doomcrown sends more hobgoblin raiders up from Arcturiadoom ({@adventure level 14|WDMM|14}) to gather metal for his fire giant masters—unless the characters take the fight to him in the meantime.

Months of work are needed to finish construction of the Simulacrux. If work on the project continues and Zox completes his arch, there's no telling whether it functions as intended. Scaladar simulacra created by the arch might be defective or uncontrollable. It's also possible that the Simulacrux might be able to create rust simulacra of other creatures besides scaladar. It's equally likely that the Simulacrux won't function at all, prompting Zox to tear it down and build another metal monstrosity in its place.

If the myconid sovereign in {@area area 12|6f4|x} survives, it releases spores to seed the scorched earth, giving rise to a new colony of myconid sprouts. The fungus forest recovers on its own, though it takes years.

data.name: Level 14: Arcturiadoom
entries: Arcturiadoom is designed for four 13th-level characters, and adventurers who defeat the monsters on this level should gain enough PX to advance halfway to 14th level. The lich Arcturia, who dwells on {@adventure level 23|WDMM|23} of Undermountain, is one of Halaster's most accomplished apprentices, arguably the most powerful of the Seven, and a master of transmutation magic. Arcturiadoom is her personal retreat ("doom" being an archaic term for a lord's domain). Hidden on this level is Arcturia's phylactery, and adventurers would be wise to find and destroy it before facing the lich in battle on {@adventure level 23|WDMM|23}.

entries.name: What Dwells Here?
entries: Arcturiadoom has been taken over by fire giants in the service of Halaster. The fire giants are accompanied by a large force of hobgoblins. Drow have also infiltrated this level of the dungeon, though they have no quarrel with adventurers.

entries.name: Fire Giants
entries: Emberosa, a fire giant, has come to Undermountain with six of her kin on a mission to raise fire giants to the top of the giant ordning, dethroning the mighty storm giants.

Emberosa hopes to obtain a lost rune of power created by the giants more than forty thousand years ago. She believes nans stole the rune from the giants and hid it under Mount Waterdeep. Halaster found the rune and hid it in on {@adventure level 23|WDMM|23}, but he has agreed to part with it if the fire giants use their exceptional metal-forging abilities to build a giant construct for him. Work is under way, with the construct being assembled in {@area area 15|730|x}.
For more information on the giant ordning, see the "Giants" entry in the {@book Monster Manual|MM}.

entries.name: Death's Head Phalanx
entries: The Death's Head Phalanx is a force of hobgoblins that came to Undermountain along with Emberosa and her fire giants. This force is commanded by a hobgoblin warlord named Doomcrown, who is the estranged son of Warlord Azrok (see {@adventure level 3|WDMM|3}).

A devout follower of the godslayer Maglubiyet, Doomcrown wants fire giants to ascend to the top of the giant ordning, envisioning their brutal tyranny sweeping across Faerûn. He expects to play an important role in Emberosa's ascension and conquest, and he dreams of ruling what remains of the High Forest once the elves and other forest denizens are purged and the trees are reduced to ashen spines.

Since arriving in Arcturiadoom, however, Doomcrown has developed strange habits. He spends more and more time locked away in his quarters, chasing some strange new obsession. His followers remain loyal, but they worry about the mental state of their warlord.

entries.name: Hobgoblin Patrols
entries: Hobgoblins of Doomcrown's phalanx have secured most of the halls and chambers in Arcturiadoom. Consequently, the only wandering monsters of consequence are hobgoblin patrols. A typical patrol consists of four {@creature Hobgoblin||hobgoblins}. Their marching footsteps and clanking armor can be heard well in advance of their arrival, and characters can't be surprised by them. Combat with a patrol is sure to alert other creatures in the vicinity.
If any hobgoblins are defeated while on patrol, subtract their numbers from the guards in {@area area 32a|764|x}.

entries.name: House Freth
entries: Three drow mages have infiltrated Arcturiadoom in the hope of securing powerful magic to conquer other levels of Undermountain. These drow belong to House Freth (see {@adventure level 12|WDMM|12}). They avoid violent confrontations with adventurers and instead try to turn them against the fire giants and the hobgoblins.

entries.name: Polymorph Traps
entries: Throughout Arcturiadoom lie magic traps designed to polymorph humanoids. (Creatures that aren't humanoids are unaffected.) These traps are marked P on map 14. The hobgoblins are aware of these traps and do their best to avoid them. A polymorph trap is marked by a nearly {@condition invisible} glyph inscribed on a 10-foot-square section of floor. A character searching the area for traps can detect the glyph with a successful DC 20 Saviesa ({@skill Percepció}) check. The first humanoid to pass over the 10-foot-square area triggers the glyph and ha de salvar per Saviesa (CD 20). Si falla, be transformed into a monster with average hit points. All items worn or carried by the creature are absorbed into its new form. The new form is hostile toward all other creatures and must attack any other creatures it can see. Roll a {@dice d10} to determine the creature's new form:

When the polymorphed creature es queda a 0 punts de vida, it reverts to its original form and is stable at 0 hit points. Once a glyph is triggered, it disappears, rendering its space safe to pass through until Arcturia sees fit to replace it. A successful dissipar màgia spell (DC 17) cast on a glyph removes it.

entries.name: Exploring This Level
entries: All location descriptions for this level are keyed to map 14.

entries.name: 1. Entrance to Arcturiadoom
entries: These caverns lie at the end of the worm-bored tunnel leading down from level 13.

entries.name: 1a. Worm Tunnel
entries: The {@creature bore worm|WDMM} on {@adventure level 13|WDMM|13} wanders down here occasionally, looping around a central column of rock before traveling back up. This column supports the cavern's 30-foot-high roof. The cavern also has these features:

{@b Double Door}. A double door is framed with carvings of worm-ridden skulls. Carved into the lintel above the double door is a sconce sculpted to resemble a skeletal hand, with a {@spell foc perenne} spell cast in its palm.
{@b Monsters}. A pair of stalagmites flank the double door. Hiding behind each stalagmite is an {@condition invisible} {@creature drow mage} and an {@condition invisible} {@creature quasit}.
{@b Rock Formations}. Around the edges of the cavern are more stalagmites and stalactites. More of these formations fill a smaller cavern to the southeast ({@area area 1b|706|x}).

The two drow mages are males named Hulziin and Yrrprek. Each wears a cloak pin bearing the insignia of House Freth. They arrived here shortly before the adventurers and have {@spell invisibilitat superior} spells cast on them. The drow and their two quasit companions try to remain hidden, allowing adventurers to move into Arcturiadoom ahead of them. Once the path is clear, they pass through {@area areas 3|70e|x} and {@area 35|76b} on their way to {@area area 38|771|x}.
One of their kin, Vanar, arrived early to scout and has already slipped inside. The characters might encounter him and his shadow demon in {@area area 29|757|x}.

entries.name: 1b. Stalactites and Stalagmites
entries: This damp, dripping cave contains a veritable forest of stalagmites and stalactites.

entries.name: 1c. Claw-Shaped Cave
entries: The drow have hidden supplies in the deepest arm of this otherwise empty cave. A search reveals three backpacks made of woven spiderwebs. Each pack contains a carmanyola, 10 dies de racions (dried mushrooms, moss, and boiled cocatriu eggs), 50 feet of spider silk rope, and a full water skin made from a lizard's bladder.

entries.name: 2. Natural Caves
entries: This small network of caves lies outside the dungeon proper and serves as home to one of Arcturia's monstrous experiments.

entries.name: 2a. Deformed Duergar
entries: Characters who enter this cave are soon attacked by a hideously deformed duergar. The creature has enlarged itself to a height of 9 feet.

This creature used to be two separate duergar, a male named Blork and a female named Muatha. Arcturia fused them together into a single creature by using magic that only a {@spell desig} spell can undo. Both skulls merged into one bulbous head that has three ears, three eyes, two noses, and two mouths. It has a third arm on the right side of its body, and its left leg splits into two at the knee, giving it three feet. The transformation drove the poor creature insane, and it regards all other creatures as threats that must be destroyed.
The creature is a {@creature duergar}, with these changes:

items: The creature has 40 hit points.
It has advantage on Saviesa ({@skill Percepció}) checks and on saving throws against being {@condition fascinat}, {@condition acovardit}, {@condition atordit}, or knocked {@condition inconscient}.
Com a acció bonus, it can make an attack with its javelina.

entries.name: 2b. Duergar's Crib
entries: The deformed creature in {@area area 2a|709|x} sleeps here on a bed of spongy black mold that grows at the back of the cave.

entries.name: 2c. Fungus Gardens
entries: The creature in {@area area 2a|709|x} comes here to feed, as do other creatures dwelling in the caverns. The cave has the following features:
{@b Fungi}. Gardens of fungus sprout from mounds of offal on the uneven floor. The fungi release clouds of dimly luminescent spores that fill the cave like a fine, hanging mist.

{@b Carrion Crawlers}. Four {@creature Carrion Crawler||carrion crawlers} dwell here. Two cling to the 10-foot-high ceiling, and two feed on the rotting corpse of a fifth carrion crawler lying amid the fungus.
The crawlers are natural enemies of the creature in {@area area 2a|709|x}, which recently killed one of them with a blow from its war pick. They ignore characters who keep a respectful distance.

A character who studies the fungus and succeeds on una tirada d'Intel·ligència ({@skill Natura}) amb CD 10 can distinguish edible varieties from poisonous ones, and also ascertains that the spore clouds are harmless. A character unaware of this information who eats fungus has a {@chance 50|50 percent} chance of consuming a poisonous variety and ha de salvar per Constitució (CD 10). Si falla, està {@condition emmetzinat} for {@dice 1d4} hours.

entries.name: 2d. Standing Gate to Level 12
entries: This cave contains a pair of standing stones with an inanimate minotaure skeleton embedded in each one, facing each other. These standing stones form one of Halaster's magic gates (see "{@area Gates|028|x}"). The rules of the gate are as follows:

items: Any creature that touches one of the standing stones is targeted by a {@spell laberint} (CD 22).
To open the gate, a creature must escape the labyrinth created by the {@spell laberint} spell. When it returns, the gate opens durant 1 minut.

Characters must be 12th level or higher to pass through this gate (see "{@area Jhesiyra Kestellharp|016|x}"). The first creature to pass through the gate triggers an elder rune (see "{@area Elder Runes|027|x}").
A creature that passes through the gate appears in {@area area 12a on level 12|67e|x}, in the closest unoccupied space next to the identical gate located there.

entries.name: 3. Foyer

entries: {@b Monsters}. Two male {@creature Fire Giant||fire giants} (named Druvax and Zelzzarf) and seven {@creature Hobgoblin||hobgoblins} are sorting through pieces of scrap iron on the floor and tossing them noisily into piles.
{@b Statues}. Two statues of nans flank the double door to the southwest. Each statue stands atop a crumbling, 2-foot-high stone block. The statues have been magically reshaped in gruesome ways.

Arcturia used {@spell moldejar la pedra} spells to mutilate the statues, which once depicted proud dwarf warriors. The statue to the west has stony pseudòpodes sprouting from it, while the statue to the south appears half-melted.

The giants and the hobgoblins aren't happy with drudge work and eagerly hurl themselves into combat if the chance presents itself. The scrap iron was brought down from {@adventure level 13|WDMM|13} and will later be transported to {@area area 14|72e|x} to be eventually melted down and recast.

entries.name: 4. Prison
entries: Arcturia confines living subjects here until she finds time to experiment on them. The 15-foot-high room is engulfed in a permanent camp antimàgic (see the {@spell camp antimàgic} spell for effects). The room has the following additional features:
{@b Cells}. Six 10-foot-high cells with arched ceilings are barred with iron portcullises. Lying in the southwest cell is a humanoid corpse clad in armadura de plaques and riddled with arrows.
{@b Lever}. Bolted to the floor in the middle of the room is a 4-foot-wide, 7-foot-long iron plate with a comb-shaped hole in it. An iron lever protrudes from the hole.

The remains in the southwest cell are those of a female orog who was captured by Arcturia and stripped of her weapons. The hobgoblins found her, shot her full of arrows through the bars, and left her corpse to rot.

The iron lever operates the mechanism that raises and lowers the portcullises by sliding it along the comb-shaped hole in the floor plate. Depending on how the lever is positioned, it can be used to raise any of the portcullises one at a time, or to lower all the portcullises into place.

The portcullises are impervious to weapon damage. The gaps between the bars are 4 inches wide. Closed portcullises are locked in place; forcing one upward requires a successful DC 26 Força ({@skill Atletisme}) check.

entries.name: 5. Side Chambers
entries: Other than a polymorph trap (see "{@area Polymorph Traps|700|x}"), these conjoined rooms contain little of note.

entries.name: 5a. Domed Chamber
entries: This room has a domed ceiling 20 feet high. It is otherwise empty.

entries.name: 5b. Teleport Destination
entries: This chamber has a flat ceiling 15 feet high. Creatures teleported from {@area area 13a|728|x} arrive here. The room is otherwise empty.

entries.name: 6. Statue of Arcturia
entries: Here marks the perpendicular intersection of two corridors, one cut short by dead ends. Beyond an archway to the southwest is a stone statue of a 6-foot-tall skeletal figure with butterfly wings sprouting from its back and sharp bone spurs on its forearms and elbows. The statue stands atop a 3-foot-high stone base. The statue clutches a stone wand and points it toward the floor.

The statue represents Arcturia and is neither magical nor animate. The statue's wand points in the direction of the polymorph trap that is set before it (see "{@area Polymorph Traps|700|x}"). Characters who search the floor for traps have advantage on checks made to detect the polymorph trap.

entries.name: 7. Statue of Halaster
entries: Set into an alcove at the back of this dusty side chamber is a nonmagical, life-size statue of Halaster Blackcloak carved from granite. The statue is thrusting its stone staff outward in a threatening manner, its visage sculpted with a look of wild abandon. Its robe is engraved with hundreds of lidless eyes. The statue stands atop a 1-foot-thick granite disk.

entries.name: Mitrall Keys
entries: A character who inspects the statue and succeeds on una tirada de Saviesa ({@skill Percepció}) amb CD 15 discovers that one of the eyes carved into Halaster's robe is a button. Pressing this button causes two keys tucked under Halaster's robes to clatter onto the floor around the statue's base. Each key is a flat, 6-inch-long piece of mitrall worked into a curious shape.
The first key is shaped like an F, the second like a V with a small loop at the bottom. These are two of the six keys required to activate the weapon of mass disintegration in {@area area 37|76e|x}.

entries.name: 8. Dwarven Crypt
entries: This room is a dusty crypt with an arched ceiling 20 feet high. It has the following features:
{@b Sarcophagi}. Four limestone sarcophagi with faded Nan inscriptions line the room's perimeter. They contain only dust, shards of bone, and strips of moldy cloth.
{@b Polymorph Trap}. One 10-foot section of floor bears a hidden polymorph trap (see "{@area Polymorph Traps|700|x}").

entries.name: 9. Death's Head Watch Post
entries: The hobgoblins of the Death's Head Phalanx have set up an outpost here to guard the foundry ({@area area 12|723|x}). Characters approaching this part of the dungeon hear the war chants of the hobgoblin phalanx in {@area area 9c|71d|x}.

entries.name: 9a. Training Room
entries: Characters who listen at the door hear guttural cheers coming from within. The room contains six {@creature Hobgoblin||hobgoblins}. Two are engaged in mock swordplay with dulled blades in the middle of the room while the other four cheer them on. The room is otherwise empty.

entries.name: 9b. Crypt
entries: A granite sarcophagus against the north wall has been opened, its lid dumped onto the floor. Dust and cobwebs cling to its sides, obscuring ancient inscriptions.

The sarcophagus contains the dusty remains of a Melairkyn dwarf entombed here thousands of years ago. The inscriptions on the sarcophagus, written in Nannès, translate as follows: "Thou hast found the final resting place of Harlsnod Darkshine—architect, trap builder, and drinker of fine ales."

entries.name: 9c. Hobgoblin Phalanx
entries: Here, a {@creature hobgoblin captain} has marshaled a phalanx of twenty {@creature Hobgoblin||hobgoblins}. The captain faces east and recites a liturgy in Goblin to the dread god Maglubiyet while the soldiers stand at attention in two rows of ten, facing west. As she reaches dramatic peaks in the liturgy, the hobgoblins grunt and nod approvingly, banging their fists on their armor.

The hobgoblins attack intruders on sight. A battle here pulls reinforcements from {@area areas 9a|71b|x}, {@area 16|733}, i {@area 18|737}. It also attracts the attention of the fire giant metalsmith in {@area area 11|721|x}.

entries.name: 10. Nans' Den

entries: {@b Tankard}. A large iron tankard sculpture has torn loose from the 30-foot-high ceiling and fallen onto a stone table in the middle of the room, cracking it in half. Toppled stools surround the broken table.
{@b Statues}. Two 4-foot-tall statues of nans stand atop 2-foot-high blocks of stone at opposite ends of the room. The head of the southern statue has broken off and lies on the floor nearby.

This cast-iron tankard once hung from the ceiling by iron chains and is big enough for four nans to crawl inside. It weighs 1,500 pounds and makes a satisfying, bell-like clanging sound when struck—and the noise draws hobgoblins from area 9c.

entries.name: Statues and Mitrall Key
entries: The north statue depicts a smiling female dwarf raising a stone tankard. Hidden in the tankard is a flat, 6-inch-long mitrall key shaped like an H missing its top left stem. This key is one of six required to activate the weapon of mass disintegration in {@area area 37|76e|x}.
The south statue depicts a headless male dwarf resting a large pair of stone tongs on one shoulder; its head cracked when it hit the floor, and it falls apart into two halves if disturbed.

entries.name: 11. Smithy
entries: Characters who listen at the doors to this room hear loud hammering from beyond. The 30-foot-high room is warm and contains the following features:
{@b Fire Giant}. In the middle of the room, a male {@creature fire giant} uses a massive hammer and anvil to pound a heated iron fragment into a rounded shape.

{@b Fire Beetles}. Resting on the floor next to the oversized anvil is an iron cage containing fifteen brightly glowing {@creature Giant Fire Beetle||giant fire beetles}. (The giant uses the cage as a lantern.)
{@b Iron Pieces}. Wings to the west and east contain pieces of sculpted iron of all shapes and sizes.

The giant, Hrossk, is hostile toward adventurers. He keeps his greatsword close at hand and hurls large metal cogs instead of rocks. Combat in this room can be heard by the fire giants in {@area area 12|723|x}, who investigate at once if a fight breaks out.

Hrossk's job is to recast hot iron into body parts for the giant construct in {@area area 15|730|x}. Without Hrossk, Emberosa lacks the metalsmithing skills needed to finish work on Mecha-Halaster. Hrossk is currently crafting a piece of what will become one of the construct's eyes.
The fire beetles can't harm anyone while confined to their cage. Unlatching the cage door requires an action. If released, the beetles attack indiscriminately.

The iron fragments littering the floor include curved sheets of outer plating, as well as internal gears, cogs, spindles, bars, and pipes. These pieces are waiting to be attached to the construct in {@area area 15|730|x}.

entries.name: 12. Melairkyn Foundry
entries: The foundry is unbearably hot. Characters who linger here durant 1 hora or more while the forges are operating are subject to the effects of extreme heat (see {@book chapter 5|DMG|5|Weather} of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}).

entries.name: 12a. Hell Hounds

entries: {@b Ceiling}. This hall has an arched, 30-foot-high ceiling.
{@b Hounds}. Five {@creature Hell Hound||hell hounds} patrol the hall. They obey the commands of fire giants and attack intruders on sight.
{@b Open Pits}. Three 10-foot-square pits in the floor contain discarded scraps of metal.

The pits are 70 feet deep but partially filled with scrap metal that reduces their effective depth. The western pit is 20 feet deep, the central pit is 50 feet deep, and the eastern pit is 10 feet deep. Any creature that falls into the pit lands on jagged shards of metal and takes slashing damage instead of dany contundent from the fall.

entries.name: 12b–12d. Elemental Forges
entries: These three identical chambers have stone stairs that climb 10 feet to each platform, at the back of which is a raging hot forge of blackened stone. The curved ceilings in these chambers are 20 feet high.

Three {@creature Fire Giant||fire giants} (two females named Dralkana and Ingritt and a male named Yarshoss) are stationed here, one at each forge. Their job is to melt down fragments of scrap iron so that Hrossk, the fire giant metalsmith in {@area area 11|721|x}, can reshape them for the construct in {@area area 15|730|x}. It's tedious work, and the fire giants are restless and spoiling for a fight.

The fires in the forges are conjured from the Elemental Plane of Fire. A stone lever built into each forge closes a valve in the back of it, extinguishing the flames. Any creature that enters a lit forge or starts its turn in one takes 55 ({@dice 10d10}) de dany de foc.

entries.name: 13. Transmutorium
entries: Arcturia keeps some of her horrific handiwork here.

entries.name: 13a. Woven Eyes

entries: {@b Pillars}. Three pillars of polished black stone stand in the corners of the room. Attached to each pillar at waist height is a tarnished silver knob.

{@b Tapestry}. A huge, sickly purple tapestry hanging on the west wall undulates as though alive. Its surface is covered with eleven unblinking eyes: one large central eye and ten small peripheral eyes. (Hidden behind the tapestry is a secret door.)
{@b Crystal Door}. A crystal door in one corner of the room stands closed. Beyond the door is a small, magically lit chamber. (See {@area area 13b|72b|x} for details.)

All three pillars and their silver knobs radiate auras of transmutation magic under the scrutiny of a {@spell detectar màgia} spell. Any creature that touches a pillar's silver knob is teleported to {@area area 5b|714|x}. Once a silver knob has teleported a creature, it disappears. Eight hours after the last knob vanishes, all three reappear.

entries.name: Tapestry of Eyes
entries: The fleshy tapestry is Xebekal, a beholder that invaded Arcturia's dungeon years ago. The lich snared the eye tyrant and used a {@spell desig} spell to transform it. In the form of a tapestry, the beholder retains its {@sense visió de foscor} and can see whatever is in front of it, but nothing behind it. It can't speak, and its movement is limited to harmless flapping. It can't use its Antimagic Cone trait or take any actions or reactions.

Xebekal can be contacted with telepathy. It promises wealth and power to anyone who restores it, but has no intention of honoring its promises. Only a {@spell desig} spell can turn the tapestry back into the beholder it once was.

The tapestry has AC 5, 33 hit points, immunity to poison damage, and vulnerability to fire damage. Si es queda a 0 punts de vida, the tapestry is destroyed. The characters gain no PX for killing the beholder in this form, given its present helplessness.

entries.name: 13b. Alteration Chamber

entries: {@b Crystal Door}. The door to this chamber is made of 3-inch-thick transparent crystal.
{@b Brass Panels}. Embedded in the wall next to the door is a brass panel with four brass buttons arranged in a diamond formation. (A similar panel appears inside the chamber.)
{@b Light}. A crystal dome in the ceiling sheds pale white light, illuminating the whole chamber.
{@b Key}. Lying on the chamber floor is a flat mitrall key.
The buttons on each brass panel and their effects are as follows:
The {@b top button} is engraved with an arrow pointing up. Pressing it opens the crystal door, which retracts into the ceiling. This button is locked and cannot be pressed if the door is already up.

The {@b bottom button} is engraved with an arrow pointing down. Pressing it shuts the crystal door by lowering it back into place. This button is locked and cannot be pressed if the door is already down.

The {@b left button} is engraved with a tiny human stick figure. The button is locked and cannot be pressed while the crystal door is open. If the button is pressed while the door is closed, the light emanating from the crystal dome on the ceiling flickers, and all creatures in the chamber behind the door magically shrink as though affected by the reduce effect of the {@spell engrandir/enxiquir} spell (no saving throw allowed). The effect lasts for 24 hours.
The {@b right button} is engraved with a larger human stick figure and functions like the left button, except the creatures in the alteration chamber are enlarged instead of reduced.

If a magically reduced creature is subjected to the chamber's enlarge effect, or a magically enlarged creature is subjected to the reduce effect, the two alterations cancel each other out, and the creature reverts to normal size. The effects of the chamber aren't cumulative—a reduced creature that is reduced again or an enlarged creature that is enlarged again doesn't change size further.

Each time the alteration chamber's reduce effect or enlarge effect is activated, roll a {@dice d6}. On a 1, the chamber malfunctions. Instead of the normal effect, all creatures inside the chamber ha de salvar per Constitució (CD 20), taking 44 ({@dice 8d10}) de dany de força; si supera, en rep la meitat. You can replace this damaging effect with a more benign one. For example, the chamber's magic might cause creatures' noses to elongate or turn their skin blue; an alteration of this sort can be undone with a {@spell restabliment superior} spell or similar magic.

entries.name: Mitrall Key
entries: The flat, 6-inch-long mitrall key is shaped like a J with a loop at the top. This key is one of six needed to activate the weapon of mass disintegration in area 37.

entries.name: 14. More Scrap Iron

entries: {@b Light}. Mounted to the diagonal walls at this intersection are four iron torch brackets with {@spell foc perenne} spells cast on them.
{@b Scrap Iron}. Heaped in the middle of the intersection is a 9-foot-high pile of scrap iron.
{@b Double Door}. A 20-foot-tall double door blocks the hallway to the north. Leering skulls are carved around the door.

The scrap metal came from level 13. Whenever the characters leave this area and return, there is a {@chance 20|20 percent} chance that Hrossk, the {@creature fire giant} metalsmith in {@area area 11|721|x}, is here to collect a choice piece of scrap iron and bring it to area 12 to be melted down and recast.

entries.name: 15. Mecha-Halaster

entries: {@b Pillar Sconces}. This hall has a 150-foot-high arched ceiling buttressed by stone pillars that have sconces protruding from them at 10-foot intervals. {@spell Foc Perenne} spells cast on the sconces illuminate the hall.

{@b Giant Construct}. In the middle of the room, lying on its back on the stone-tiled floor, is a 100-foot-tall figure made of molded iron, its feet pointing toward the double door to the south. The construct is missing its head, and there are gaps in its outer shell through which the construct's inner supports and mechanisms can be glimpsed.

{@b Emberosa}. This female {@creature fire giant} has 221 hit points and the innate magical ability to hurl fire at will (as the fire giant's Rock attack option, except it deals fire damage). She stands on the construct's chest, 20 feet above the floor. Flitting around her are her sidekicks, three {@creature Smoke Mephit||smoke mephits}.
{@b Pit}. At the north end of the room is a 20-foot-deep pit with a dusty stone sarcophagus at the bottom.

Emberosa is inspecting the work of her fellow fire giants and doesn't want to be disturbed. To say she has a temper would be an understatement. If intruders enter the hall, she tries to make quick work of them while her mephits taunt the new arrivals mercilessly. A battle here brings reinforcements rapidly from {@area areas 16|733|x} and 18.

The construct is made of recast bits of scrap iron plundered from Trobriand's Graveyard ({@adventure level 13|WDMM|13}). When complete, the construct will be the spitting image of Halaster Blackcloak himself—100 feet tall and made of iron. When the time comes to conquer Waterdeep, the Mad Mage plans to use Mecha-Halaster to destroy the city's walking statues. Without its head and the immense magic needed to power it, the iron construct is nothing more than a giant boondoggle. In its current state, it is considered an inanimate object, not a creature. Medium or smaller creatures that squeeze inside it can use the outer shell and inner mechanisms as cover. Bigger creatures can't fit inside the construct.

entries.name: Pit and Sarcophagus
entries: A character needs climbing gear or magic to scale the walls of the pit, which are made of smooth stone.

The sarcophagus at the bottom of the pit has a bas-relief of a laughing dwarf carved into its lid, the rim of which bears the following inscription in Nan: "Here lies Lulz Klangphorn, trapsmith. He is survived by his work." The lid can be pushed aside with a singular or combined Força of 18. The sarcophagus contains nothing but dust, bones, and Lulz's bronzed skull.

Removing Lulz's skull from the sarcophagus causes mechanisms in the surrounding walls to grind and clank loudly, as though a complex trap has been set in motion. The effect, though harmless, is meant to frighten tomb robbers. After 1 minute, the noise stops.

entries.name: 16. Death's Head Looters

entries: {@b Sarcophagi}. Three dusty stone sarcophagi lie in a row in the middle of the room. Their flat stone lids have been pried off and cast aside.
{@b Hobgoblins}. Unless they have been drawn elsewhere, six {@creature Hobgoblin||hobgoblins} are rummaging through the sarcophagi.
{@b Secret Door}. A secret door in the north wall opens into {@area area 17|735|x}. (The hobgoblins are unaware of the door.)
The hobgoblins, searching aimlessly for anything valuable, gang up on foes to quickly take them down.

Each sarcophagus contains the desiccated corpses of {@dice 1d3} humanoids in scorched robes, lying atop the dust of the ancient dead. The corpses are those of Arcturia's past apprentices and assistants, each of whom displeased her in some way and paid the ultimate price.

entries.name: 17. Hidden Storeroom
entries: This chamber is hidden behind secret doors and choked with dust and cobwebs. It has the following features:

{@b Casks}. Five heavy carrying-casks (barrels 3 feet long and 2 feet in diameter with sturdy rope handles) are stacked in the middle of the room. The ale inside them turned to vinegar and evaporated long ago.
{@b Crate}. Next to the casks is a brittle crate containing sixty-six small brass oil lamps shaped like dragon heads with open, smiling jaws. Each lamp has a wick, but there's no oil to be found.
{@b Stool}. A three-legged stool lies on its side in the northeast corner. The bones of a dead stirge are nearby.
{@b Hobgoblins}. Unless they have been drawn elsewhere, four {@creature Hobgoblin||hobgoblins} guard this room. They gang up on foes, trying to take them down quickly.
{@b Debris}. Smashed wooden crates and furnishings piled along the walls are shrouded in dust and cobwebs.
{@b Secret Door}. A secret door in the south wall opens into {@area area 17|735|x}. (The hobgoblins are unaware of the door.)

entries.name: 19. Storerooms
entries: Hanging from the handles of the doors to these rooms are wooden signs that read "KEEP OUT!" in Common.

entries.name: 19a. Spell Component Storage

entries: {@b Stove}. An iron stove stands against the south wall.
{@b Coffers}. Rows of dusty niches line the walls. Roughly half of the niches contain small wooden coffers.

The stove was given a semblance of life through an {@spell animar objectes} spell made permanent by a {@spell desig} spell. It tears free of its stovepipe and charges forward on clawed feet to attack intruders.

The stove is a Large construct with a challenge rating of 3 (700 PX). It has AC 17, 50 hit points, a walking speed of 30 feet, and the following ability scores: Força 14, Destresa 10, Constitució 10, Intel·ligència 3, Saviesa 3, and Carisma 1. It has {@sense visió a cegues} out to a range of 30 feet and is blind beyond this distance. It has the following opcions d'acció:

entries.name: Colpeig
entries: {@i Atac armat cos a cos}: +6 a impactar, 5 peus d'abast, un objectiu. {@i Hit}: 11 ({@dice 2d8 + 2}) de dany contundent.

entries.name: Belch Fire (Recharge 4–6)
entries: The stove belches fire en un con de 15 peus. Tota criatura dins de l'àrea ha de salvar per Destresa (CD 10), taking 22 ({@dice 4d10}) de dany de foc; si supera, en rep la meitat.

entries.name: Tresor
entries: There are twenty-four wooden coffers in all, each one labeled in Common with the name of a spell and containing all the material components for one or more castings of that spell. The following table summarizes the coffers' contents:

rows: Three vials of human blood, three strips of flesh, and a pouch of bone dust ({@spell animar els morts})
Three patches of bat fur ({@spell ull arcà})
A cocatriu eggshell and a snakeskin glove ({@i Mà d'en Bigby})
A tuft of quaggoth fur, a piece of amber, and three silver pins ({@spell llamp en cadena})
A pouch containing the powder of a crushed black pearl worth 500 gp ({@spell cercle de la mort})
A pouch of soot and a pouch of salt ({@spell comprendre idiomes})
Three shards of pale white crystal ({@spell con de fred})
A small clay pot filled with grave dirt, a small clay pot filled with brackish water, and a black onyx stone worth 150 gp ({@spell crear no-morts})
Three lodestones and a pouch of dust ({@spell desintegrar})
A pouch of sand, a jar of ink, and a writing quill ({@spell somnis})
Eight squid tentacles ({@spell Evard's black tentacles})
Ten feathers ({@spell descens de ploma} or {@spell volar})
Nine tiny balls of bat guano and sulfur ({@spell bola de foc})
A block of incense worth 250 gp and four ivory strips worth 50 gp each ({@spell recordar llegendes})
A black crystal dodecahedron worth 500 gp ({@spell gerra màgica})
Three adder stomachs and a pouch containing powdered rhubarb leaves ({@spell Fletxa Àcida d'en Melf})
A vial holding ten pinches of diamond dust worth 25 gp per pinch ({@spell indetectable})
A spool of copper wire ({@spell encàrrec})
A pouch of fine sand ({@spell adormir})
Eight tiny jars of ointment for the eyes worth 25 gp each, made from mushroom powder, saffron, and fat ({@spell visió veritable})
A ball of string with toothpicks stuck in it ({@spell servent invisible})
Two pieces of phosphorus ({@spell paret de foc})
Ten small pieces of straw ({@spell water breathing})

entries.name: 19b. Inanimate Objects
entries: Scattered about this room are inanimate objects that Arcturia animates using the {@i animar objectes} spell:

items: A brass brazier set atop a 3-foot-high tripod and a wooden broom (Small objects)
A wooden coat rack; an iron torture chair festooned with spikes; a 10-foot-long, 250-pound chain; and a fat iron cauldron (Medium objects)
A stone mine cart and a life-size, hollow bronze statue of a bull (Large objects)

entries.name: 20. Supplies
entries: Two {@creature Hobgoblin||hobgoblins} are stationed outside this room, one in front of each door. Their orders are to guard the food supplies. A battle here alerts the hobgoblins in {@area area 32|763|x}, who arrive quickly to aid their allies.

The room is packed with crates of rations and barrels of fresh water, with narrow aisles meandering between the containers. The giants and the hobgoblins rely on this supply, and there's enough food and water to last for weeks.

entries.name: 21. Night and Day

entries: {@b Timekeeper}. Four pillars support the 20-foot-high ceiling. An iron ring 20 feet in diameter is suspended from iron brackets affixed to the tops of the pillars so that it hangs parallel to the floor 20 feet below. Nested inside this ring is a circular iron disk of slightly smaller diameter with a symbol of the sun embossed on one side and a symbol of the moon on the opposite side. Directly above the ring and the disk is a 10-foot-deep, dome-shaped concavity in the ceiling.
{@b Statues}. Nestled in alcoves are two life-size statues of robed human wizards, their faces obscured under stony cowls and their arms raised toward the iron disk.

This room is one large timekeeping device. Every day at dawn and at dusk, the wizard statues exert {@condition invisible} magical force upon the suspended iron disk, causing it to flip over within its circular frame like a coin. During the day, the sun symbol is visible on the disk's underside; at night, the disk displays the moon symbol on its underside. When the disk rotates, half of it swings up into the dome-shaped concavity in the ceiling. The lower half swings downward, with 10 feet of clearance between its outer edge and the floor.

A {@spell detectar màgia} spell reveals auras of evocation magic and transmutation magic around the statues, which defy all attempts to move or break them. If a creature attempts to turn the disk manually, the statues discharge lightning that fills the room. All creatures in the room at that moment ha de salvar per Destresa (CD 18), taking 22 ({@dice 4d10}) de dany elèctric; si supera, en rep la meitat. Creatures in direct contact with the iron ring or the disk, as well as creatures clad in metal armor, have disadvantage on the saving throw.

entries.name: 22. Arcane Scribblings

entries: {@b Chalkboards}. Mounted on the walls are several blackboards on which arcane phrases and formulas are written in chalk.

{@b Table Trap}. A wooden table in the middle of the room bears a collection of dusty flasks and beakers. The table is draped in cobwebs and obviously hasn't been disturbed in a long time. The paraphernalia is meant to distract viewers from the polymorph trap upon which the table rests (see "{@area Polymorph Traps|700|x}").

The chalk scribblings were left by one of Arcturia's failed apprentices. Any character who studies the markings and succeeds on una tirada d'Intel·ligència ({@skill Arcana}) amb CD 16 can tell that they are attempts by one individual to unravel the secrets of spells beyond their comprehension. Spellcasters who have the {@spell desintegrar} i {@spell carn a pedra} spells on their spell lists can tell that those are the spells being researched, though neither spell can be learned from these incomplete scribblings.
Sounds of battle in this room can be heard by the hobgoblin guards in {@area area 25|74e|x}, who investigate if alerted. (They approach from the east.)

entries.name: 23. Experiments
entries: The doors to these rooms have {@spell pany arcà} spells cast on them that allow Arcturia alone to pass. A door can be forced open with a successful DC 25 Força ({@skill Atletisme}) check.

entries.name: 23a. Shoe Hulk
entries: Lying in the middle of this room is an old shoe with a {@creature scorpion} hiding in it. If the shoe is disturbed, the scorpion scuttles out and attacks the nearest creature.

The scorpion is, in fact, an {@creature umber hulk} under the effect of a {@spell polimorfia} spell made permanent with a {@spell desig} spell. The umber hulk reverts to its true form and attacks when its scorpion form is reduced to 0 hit points.

entries.name: 23b. Bad Blades
entries: A corroded steel helm rests atop a pile of rusty swords in the middle of the room. Quan una altra criatura enters the room, the pile of swords gathers into a vaguely humanoid form with the helm surmounting it and attacks. This assemblage of rusty steel has the statistics of {@creature animated armor}, except that its attacks deal piercing damage instead of dany contundent.

entries.name: 23c. Rodent of Unusual Size

entries: {@b Monster}. A giant two-headed rat (use {@creature death dog} statistics) is trapped here. This rodent is the size of a human and is hostile toward all intruders.
{@b Meat Chute}. In the ceiling near the north wall is a rectangular opening, 12 inches long by 6 inches wide, that forms the mouth of a stone chute leading up.

Every few hours, a brick of rotting meat slides down the chute from a hidden chamber above. The meat hits the floor with a wet smack and is promptly eaten by the monstrous rodent. A Tiny or gaseous creature can access this small, hidden chamber by climbing up the chute. There are no exits from the upper room, which contains only hundreds of bricks of pink, rotting meat and a magical mechanism that pushes them down the chute at random intervals. It's impossible to discern what sort of creature the meat has been harvested from.

entries.name: 23d. Guffaw the Stone Eater
entries: This room contains the smashed remains of a dwarf statue and a plump {@creature gnom de les profunditatse (svirfneblin)} named Guffaw Gravelstock, who was plucked from his Underdark gem mine by Arcturia. He is unfamiliar with Undermountain.

Arcturia's magic has given the gnome an insatiable appetite for carved stone. He uses his war pick to break up the statue and is devouring it slowly, one piece at a time. He can't keep himself from stopping to eat any carved stone he sees—and there's no end to how much he can consume. He begs to be left alone so he can finish his meal in peace. A successful {@spell dissipar màgia} spell (DC 19) cast on Guffaw rids him of his unique magical malady.

entries.name: Tresor
entries: The instant he is cured of his malady, Guffaw coughs up two diamonds (5,000 gp each). He is just as surprised to see the gemstones as anyone else, and he offers them to the characters as a reward for "saving" him. He then seeks out a way back to the Underdark, wanting nothing more to do with Undermountain.
{@b Chalkboard}. A blackboard covers the entire east wall. Written across it in big chalk letters are the words "YOU ALL FAIL!" in Common.

{@b Desks}. Whenever a creature enters the room, seven stone desks magically rise from the floor, facing the blackboard in an arc. (The desks sink back into the floor when all creatures leave the room.)
{@b Secret Door}. A secret door in the south wall pushes open to reveal a dusty, web-choked passage between this room and {@area area 25|74e|x}.
{@b Guards}. Two {@creature Hobgoblin||hobgoblins} stand guard here, one in front of each door. They attack intruders, ganging up on one enemy at a time.
{@b Arch}. A stone arch embedded in the middle of the east wall has an image of an open book carved into its keystone.
{@b Secret Door}. A secret door in the north wall opens into a dusty, web-choked passage between this room and {@area area 24|74c|x}.

entries.name: Arch Gate to Level 9
entries: The arch is one of Halaster's magic gates (see "Gates"). Its rules are as follows:

items: Holding an open book while standing within 5 feet of the arch causes the gate to open durant 1 minut. The book turns to dust as the gate opens, even if it is a spellbook.

Characters must be 10th level or higher to pass through this gate (see "{@area Jhesiyra Kestellharp|016|x}"). The first creature to pass through the gate triggers an elder rune (see "{@area Elder Runes|027|x}").
A creature that passes through the gate appears in {@area area 49 on level 9|4e3|x}, in the closest unoccupied space next to the identical gate located there.

entries.name: 26. Apprentice's Quarters
entries: Like her former master Halaster, Arcturia takes on apprentices of her own from time to time, but they seldom survive for long. This room contains a moldy quilt draped over a stone bier against the north wall and a wooden desk with a high-backed chair in the southeast corner. On one corner of the desk rests a yellowed human skull topped with a half-melted wax candle.

entries.name: 27. Dead Apprentice

entries: {@b Quilt}. A moldy quilt is draped over a stone bier against the south wall.
{@b Desk}. A wooden desk stands in the northeast corner. Slumped in a high-backed chair behind the desk is a human skeleton clad in perforated black robes.

The inanimate skeleton belongs to a human apprentice named Kazvark, whom Arcturia killed with a barrage of missils màgics for failing to complete a simple homework assignment. Arcturia destroyed Kazvark's spellbook but didn't check his pockets for valuables.

entries.name: Mitrall Key
entries: Characters who search the apprentice's robes find a 6-inch-long, flat piece of mitrall shaped like a U in one pocket. This key is one of six required to activate the weapon of mass disintegration in {@area area 37|76e|x}.

entries.name: 28. Specimens
entries: Characters who listen at either door to this room hear strange clicking noises from beyond.
{@b Hook Horror}. A {@creature hook horror} is trapped in the room, but there's more to it than meets the eye.
{@b Shelves}. The curved walls are lined with stone shelves.
{@b Smashed Jars}. Hundreds of jars of body parts lie smashed on the floor.

A hobgoblin accidentally set off a polymorph trap and was transformed into this hook horror. The other hobgoblins decided to trap it in this room as a joke. Lacking hands, the hook horror couldn't open the doors to escape, and it swept the bottles off the shelves in a rage, spilling their contents.

When the hook horror es queda a 0 punts de vida, it turns back into an {@condition inconscient} {@creature hobgoblin} named Jarrk. Despite his recent misadventure, Jarrk is fanatically loyal to Doomcrown and would never willingly betray him.

Arcturia collected body parts from all sorts of Underdark specimens. Characters who search through the detritus find moth wings, beetle shells, darkmantle eyes, stirge hooks, flumph tendrils, troglodita claws, demon ichor, gelatinous residue, and other worthless creepy bits. At your discretion, some useful spell components might lie amid the refuse.

entries.name: 29. Laboratory

entries: {@b Vanar Freth}. A {@creature drow mage} named Vanar Freth and his summoned {@creature shadow demon} companion are quietly searching the room when the characters arrive.
{@b Statues}. Standing in opposite corners are two 9-foot-tall statues of ogres transforming into giant flies.

{@b Table}. A large stone table stands in the middle of the room. Several curious items rest atop it, including a black cube-shaped box on a folded gray blanket, and the slimy, decapitated head of a mind flayer whose headless body has bled out on the floor nearby. The corpse is being feasted on by maggots.
{@b Old Trap}. The double door to the southwest and the floor around it are scorched by fire—the result of a trap set off long ago.

The drow mage has managed to get this far without being detected. Left to his own devices, he eventually finds the treasure hidden under the table (see "Treasure" below). The shadow demon watches for trouble while the drow busies himself with the search.

Vanar fights to keep any treasure he has found but otherwise avoids hostilities. Once his search of Arcturiadoom is complete, he plans to return to the House Freth fortress on {@adventure level 12|WDMM|12} and report to his master, Drivvin Freth.

entries.name: Table
entries: Until recently, Arcturia had a mind flayer assistant. She tore off its head to study the psychic energy stored in its brain. Next to the head is a long pair of steel tweezers and a ladle.

The 1-foot black cube is an ebony-framed box fitted with panes of black glass. The box has a hinged lid and radiates an aura of transmutation magic under the scrutiny of a {@spell detectar màgia} spell. When a Tiny beast small enough to fit in the box (such as a rat or a lizard) is placed inside and the lid is closed tightly, the box magically transforms it into some other Tiny beast (escull) unless it succeeds on a DC 15 Saviesa saving throw. The box can do this eight more times before its magic is fully spent, whereupon it crumbles to sand.

The folded gray blanket upon which the box rests is, in fact, the carefully removed skin of a doppelganger. Other items on the table include a jar of cocatriu tongues, a block of soft clay (the material component for the {@spell moldejar la pedra} spell) wrapped in moist cloth, and a wooden coffer labeled "Polymorph" containing a dozen caterpillar cocoons (material components for the {@spell polimorfia} spell).

entries.name: Tresor
entries: Hidden in the floor under the table is a small secret compartment that can be discovered with a successful DC 20 Saviesa ({@skill Percepció}) check. It contains a jade circlet worth 1,500 gp (the material component for a {@spell canviaformes} spell) and a {@item spell pergamí} of {@spell polimorfia}.

entries.name: 30. Hideous Transmutació

entries: {@b Carrion Ogre}. Lying on the floor in the middle of the room, held down with chains, is a creature that has the body of an ogre and the head of a carrion crawler.
{@b Body Parts}. The ogre's severed head and the carrion crawler's decapitated body lie discarded in the northern corner of the room, where they have begun to putrefy and emit a dreadful stench.
{@b Key Anell}. Hanging from a stone peg on the northwest wall is an iron ring with three keys.

The creature chained to the floor is alive, having survived a ghastly magical ritual that can't be reversed or undone. It is malnourished and must feed on carrion to survive. The chains around it are looped through iron rings bolted to the floor and secured with three heavy padlocks, which can be unlocked with the keys hanging on the wall.
